headline: TWENTIETH CENTURY CHRISTIANITY, BY DR. CHAS. W. ELIOT

headline: "THE WISCONSIN IDEA"; Prof. John R. Commons Studies Certain Phases of Recent Labor Contests and Writes of Utilitarian Idealism LABOR AND ADMINISTRATION. By John N.R. Commons. Professor of Political Economy. University of Wisconsin. New York: Macmillan Company. $1.00.
leadPara: WISCONSIN is an easy leader among the progressive Western States, and Prof. Commons is an economic Lochinvar who hoists reform upon his hobby as gallantly as did the knight of Sir Walter Scott when he "came out of the West" to woo his bride. headline: ONE TIME "HOBO" PLANS BIG REFORMS TO HELP CITY'S NEEDY; John A. Kingsbury, Now Commissioner of Charities, Knows What It Is to Sleep on the Soft Side of a Board and that Knowledge Will Help Him Solve Big Problems for the City.

headline: MOOSE TO GO IT ALONE.; West Virginia Progressives Reject Republican Fusion.

headline: AUTO DEATH TOLL SHOWS BIG GROWTH; Motor Cars Killed More in This City in 1913 Than All Other Kinds of Traffic Combined.
leadPara: There were 580 persons killed by vehicles in the streets of New York in 1913, according to the report of the National Highways Protective Society issued yesterday, and of these deaths 302 were due to automobiles. Trolley cars killed 108 persons and wagons killed 170. To show how the peril of the streets is increasing, these 580 deaths must be compared with 532 deaths in 1912 and 426 deaths in 1911.

headline: FACTORY LAW TO END 5TH AVE. CONGESTION; Under Occupancy Clause, Operative on Feb. 1, Many Garment Factories Must Move.
leadPara: After an investigation of 120 typical garment factories of the 700 on or near Fifth Avenue, tile Fifth Avenue Association yesterday reported a solution of the problem of congestion of workers on the avenue with attendant depreciation of real estate values. The solution, according to the association's report, lies in the enforcement of the "occupancy law" of the new factory law's of 1913, which went into effect on Feb. 1.

headline: FRIEND OF LINCOLN COMPARES POLITICS THEN AND NOW; Murray Nelson, Doorkeeper of the Convention That Named the Railsplitter, in His Eighty-fourth Year Chats Delightfully About the Days Since the Birth of the Republican Part.
leadPara: IT was in 1856 that I spent the day with Abraham Lincoln at Springfield, Ill., talking over with him the far-reaching political changes that were then shaking the country. A vast social upheaval was then in preparation; few then foresaw the extent to which the underlying forces, already drawing to a sanguinary conflict between privilege and equal opportunity, would rend the fabric of the nation before the final triumph of our ancient ideal of democracy."

leadPara: Andrew Carnegie received a telegram from President Wilson informing him of the plan to mediate the Mexican trouble while he was attending the final concert of the Oratorio Society at Carnegie Hall last night, and, flushed with excitement, Mr. Carnegie ran from his box in the first tier down to the stage to pass the news along to the audience.
abstract: reads telegram from Pres. Wilson at Oratorio Society concert announcing plan of South American countries to mediate in Mexican crisis; discusses his peace plan

headline: SUBURBAN PROPERTY IN GOOD DEMAND FOR HOME SALE
leadPara: SINCE the advent of Spring and milder weather, there has been a steadily increasing demand for homes in many parts of Westchester County. The leadingbrokers in White Plains, Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, and Yonkers are unanimous in predicting a better realty and building year than last season. Evidences of these improved times may be seen in many places.

headline: CHOICE RESIDENTIAL COMMUNITIES ON LONG ISLAND SHOWING MARKED EVIDENCES OF PROSPEROUS GROWTH; Continued Demand for Large Country Estates in North Shore Section -- George D. Pratt's New Home at Glen Cove -- Building Active at Great Neck, Plandome, Huntington, Jamaica and Richmond Hill -- Great Harbor at Brightwaters and South Shore Improvements.
leadPara: INDICATIONS that Long Island, in all of its popular home communities, is preparing for one of the most active seasons in its history, have been apparent during the last few weeks. From a real estate standpoint the future gives promise of much better things than last season.

headline: THE REAL ESTATE FIELD; University Heights Lots Bring Total of $284,400 at Auction -- Builder Buys Fort Washington Apartment Site -- Mrs. Vanderbilt Leases Long Island Home -- Big Commercial Leases.
PICKETS TO HAUNT J.D. ROCKEFELLER, JR.; They'll Wear Crepe on Their Arms to Remind Him of the Fatalities in Colorado.
leadPara: The offices of John D. Rockefeller, Jr., at 26 Broadway, will be picketed this morning by men and women in funeral garb in an attempt "to carry home to the young Standard Oil millionaire the message of the suffering miners in Colorado," provided plans made last night by Upton Sinclair and other strike sympathizers at the Liberal Club are carried out.
abstract: office in N. Y. will be picketed by Upton Sinclair and other strike sympathizers

headline: FOR EMPLOYMENT BUREAU.; Murdock Presents Bill Go Attach One to Federal Labor Department.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Representative Victor Murdock of Kansas, the Progressive leader, asked Congress to-day, in a bill he introduced in the House, to establish a "Bureau of Employment" in the Department of Labor, to lessen the amount of unemployment in the United States.
abstract: Introduced by Repr. Murdock; bureau to be in Dept. of Labor

Roosevelt dated Manaos, Brazil. The dispatch stated that all had arrived safely, but that Col. Roosevelt was suffering from a slight illness.
abstract: receives message from Col. Roosevelt

INDIAN WOMEN SOLVE AN OLD SEX QUESTION; Squaws Prove Conclusively That Females Dress to Satisfy the Males of the Race.
leadPara: The mooted question as to whether women dress to please men or themselves has been settled at last. The Indian Squaws of 101 Ranch, now at the Madison Square Garden, have decided it.

headline: MOOSE TICKET IN NEBRASKA; State Convention Set for July 28 -- No Chance for Fusion.

headline: NEWS OF BOOKS; Some Forthcoming Novels -- Publications in Various Departments
leadPara: THAT amoebic profession, engineering, has just produced another occupation which Mr. Percy Mackaye has christened "Dramatic Engineering." He explains just what it is in the preface of "St. Louis: A Civic Masque," which Doubleday, Page Co. will publish within a week or two.

headline: ATHLETICS FOR GIRLS STRENUOUS IN WEST; Dr. Jessie Newkirk, Education Expert of Kansas City, Kan., Approves Eastern Methods.
leadPara: Dr. Jessie Newkirk, member of the Board of Education of Kansas City, Kan., left yesterday for Chicago after an inspection on Friday of the Horace Mann School, the Washington Irving High School and Miss Scudder's School. She will confer with Mrs. Ella Flagg Young at Chicago and see some of the St. Louis high schools for girls on her way home.

headline: GEN. TRACY ON "A B C" MEDIATION AND OTHER QUESTIONS; At 84, Secretary of the Navy in the Cabinet That Made First Step Toward South American Understanding, Discusses Significance of Action Taken by Southern Powers.
leadPara: IT does not fall to the lot of many men to be in the front of public affairs for half a century, to hold places among the highest in the gift of nation and State, then to retire from politics and continue in the ardent pursuit of professional work, and at eighty-four to be still actively engaged in important affairs.

headline: CITY'S NEW "BOSS" -- EMPLOYES' CONFERENCE COMMITTEE; Chamberlain Bruere's Latest Suggestion to Secure Efficiency of Office Holders Is to Make Them Feel That the City's Business Is Their Own.
leadPara: NEW YORK has had many bosses, every one of whom relied upon control of city "jobs" for power. Traffic in salaried positions was the principal business carried on by a long series of administrations. Where this trafficking began I do not know.

headline: AMMONS TO THWART IMPEACHMENT PLAN; Colorado Democrats Back Governor as Legislature Meets to Deal with Strike.

headline: LEGISLATURE MEETS WITH STRIFE ABLAZE; Republican Assembly and Democratic Senate Still at Odds Over Appropriations.
leadPara: ALBANY, N.Y., May 4. -- A continuance of the disagreement between the Democratic Senate and the Republican Assembly, and a consequent failure to pass the financial legislation essential to keep the administrative machinery of the State moving, was the outlook as the Legislature convened to-night in extraordinary session.
abstract: Republican Assembly and Democratic Senate at odds over appropriations, Gov. Glynn's message

headline: PASS TRUST BILLS BY JULY 1, THE PLAN; President and Underwood Agree on Programme, Including Rural Credits Bill.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, May 4. -- After a conference with President Wilson Majority Leader Underwood announced to-day that an agreement had been reached to put through the Clayton Omnibus Anti-Trust bill, the Covington Interstate Trade Commission bill, and the bill to regulate the issue of stock securities, as well as a rural credits measure, before Congress adjourns.
abstract: confers' with Pres. Wilson on bills that must be passed before Congress adjourns

headline: GARFIELD DISCUSSES R.R. RATE PROBLEM; Progressive Talks to Trust Company Officials and Transportation Men.
leadPara: James R. Garfield, the Ohio Progressive leader and former Secretary of the Interior, and Newton D. Baker, Mayor of Cleveland, the disciple and successor of Tom L. Johnson, were the only speakers at the annual dinner of the Trust Company Section of the American Bankers' Association at the Waldorf last night.
abstract: problem discussed by J. R. Garfield and N. D. Baker at dinner of Amer. Bankers' Assoc.

headline: THE OPPORTUNITY OF SOUTH AMERICA.
leadPara: The representatives of the three chief South American Republics who have tendered their good offices to the United States to promote the attainment of peace and order in the territory of Mexico have conducted themselves with dignity and good sense and with an obvious purpose to feel their way gradually to their object without inviting unnecessary difficulties.
abstract: The opportunity of S. Amer.

headline: ROOSEVELT TELLS OF DISCOVERIES
leadPara: PARA, May 5. -- Col Theodore Roosevelt, who, with his son, Kermlt, arrived here today on tile steamer Dunstan from Manaos, was greeted on board by a representative of the Governor of the State of Para, by the municipal authorities, and by a number of other prominent personages.
abstract: arrives at Para, greeted by officials, tells of discovery of new river, letters from Leo Miller to Mr. Chapman of Amer. Museum

headline: BECKER AGAIN ON TRIAL TO-DAY; Chauffeur Cohen, Expected to be Defense's Mainstay, Turns State's Evidence.

headline: BARES CAMPAIGN FOR HIGHER RATES; Letters Seeking to Aid Railroads' Cause Read to Senate by Mr. La Follette.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Senator La Follette of Wisconsin, a radical Republican with Presidential aspirations, today bitterly denounced the railroads for the campaign of publicity he said they had been waging for a year to force the Interstate Commerce Commission to grant the 5 per cent. freight rate increases.
abstract: Loses customs protest on wool suits

headline: STATE MAY FORCE FOES TO ARBITRATE; Bill for Compulsory Settlement of All Strike Introduced in Colorado Legislature.
leadPara: DENVER, May 5. -- The opposing factions in the State Legislature, in special session to deal with the Colorado strike situation, averted a clash to-day by the early adjournment of both houses until to-morrow. The introduction of four bills and several resolutions, all pertaining to subjects outlined in the call of Gov. Ammons for the special session, constituted the day's work.
abstract: four bills and several resolutions dealing with strike situation introduced

headline: TWO BATTLESHIPS FAVORED BY HOUSE; "Small Navy" Advocates Meet Overwhelming Defeat in Votes on Test Motions. NEXT YEAR'S BILL SIMILAR Naval Affairs Committee Chairman Gives Notice That Two More Battleships Will Be Asked For.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, May 5. -- After a week of bitter oratorical contest, the "small navy" forces were routed by the "big navy" contingent in the House to-day and the Administration's two-battleship programme was saved with votes to spare.
abstract: proposes to eliminate battleship provision of naval appropriation bill

headline: REJECT ROCKEFELLER AID.; Amendment Accepted in Senate -- Ashurst Denounces Carnegie Also.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, May 5. -- After considerable discussion Chairman Gore of the Senate Committee on Agriculture accepted to-day an amendment to the Agricultural Appropriation bill forbidding the Government to receive assistance in its farm demonstration work from any of the Rockefeller Foundations.
abstract: elected Associate founder of Amer. Museum of Natural History

headline: GLYNN APPEALS TO PARTIES; Asks Them to Agree on Able Men for Constitutional Convention.

headline: BUY AN OLD LONDON FIRM.; Harrods Acquire the Controlling Interest in Dickens & Jones.
abstract: Buys store of Dickens & Jones, London

headline: APPEAL TO WILSON IS COLORADO PLAN; Progressives Want Sweeping Powers Given to Legislature to Deal with the Strike.
leadPara: DENVER, May 6. -- The virtual refusal of Gov. Ammons late to-day to enlarge the scope of his call for the special session of the Legislature so as to include all questions involved in the strike disorders resulted in the forming of a vigorous programme by the Progressive Party members of the House.
abstract: memorial from Denver Typographical Union calling for impeachment proceedings read in State Senate

headline: COLORADO SENATE CONDEMNS AMMONS; Progressive Democrats and Moose Win First Victory Over Governor's Strike Policy.
leadPara: DENVER, May 7. -- The Progressive Democrats and the Progressives to-day joined forces in the Senate, and placed on record a resolution condemning the Ammons Administration for its failure to control the Colorado strike situation. In the House a resolution was introduced directing the Governor to extend his call for the special sessions to such an extent that the entire strike situation may be gone into.
abstract: Senate places on record resolution condemning Ammons administration and adopts resolution commanding the Governor to give names of officers and men who took part in Ludlow killing; resolution introduced in House directing him to extend his call for special sessions

headline: ATTACKS LEGALITY OF VOORHIS CHARGES; Attorney Says Two Other Elections Superintendents Must Be Named as Defendants.
leadPara: Charged with inefficiency and "failing to use the powers given to him to insure a clean and fair election in 1913," John R. Voorhis, State Superintendent of Elections, faced the Commissioner appointed by Gov. Glynn to hear the charges at the Bar Association yesterday. The Commissioner, who is John D. McMahon of Oneida County, will report the testimony and his recommendations to the Governor.
abstract: appears for Honest Ballot Assoc. in charges against John R. Voorhis in State elections of 1913

headline: BULL MOOSE VOTE SLUMPING WITH EVERY NEW ELECTION; No Increase Anywhere Except in Massachusetts, While in Many Places It Has Nearly Disappeared -- Republicans Ahead in California -- Standpatters Recapture Organization in South Dakota.
leadPara: IN the great Bull Moose State of California there is a law providing that every two years there shall be a registration of voters, at which each voter shall declare his or her party affiliation. That registration has now been proceeding since Jan. 1, and will end on July 1.

headline: Four Newspaper Men Are Thrown Into Cells on Reaching City.; TWO BRITISHERS ARE FREED And Later an American -- R.H. Davis and Medill McCormick Were Not Molested. ONE CAPTIVE REACHES COAST A.J. Rorke Tells of Huerta Massing Troops Toward Vera Cruz for Final Stand. CITY SLEEPS OVER VOLCANO Foreigners Admit They Expect a Massacre There if Our Army Starts. GIRLS TAKEN OFF HIS TRAIN Their Father, an American Railroad Man, Removed, and Mexican Soldiers Force Them to Follow HUERTA PUTS FOUR AMERICANS IN JAIL
leadPara: VERA CRUZ, May 9. -- With the arrival here to-day from Mexico City of Alfred J. Rorke, a correspondent of The Central News of America, it became known that Walter C. Whiffen, an Associated Press correspondent, and A.J. Sutton, a photographer for The Washington Post, had been thrown into prison on their arrival in the capital Thursday night.
abstract: A. J. Rorke's version of dismissal of Portillo

headline: SUFFRAGISTS ASK CONGRESS FOR VOTE; Present 531 Petitions Urging Passage of Bristow-Mondell Resolution.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Stepping briskly to the music of ten bands, the largest procession of woman suffragists ever seen in Washington marched down Pennsylvania Avenue to the Capitol to-day and presented 581 resolutions, each addressed to a particular Senator or Representative.

headline: STABILIZING REAL ESTATE VALUES A NEW YORK NEED; Incredible Past Mistakes Responsible for Depreciations -- The Folly of Too Wide Suburban Streets -- We Need Not Duplicate Europe's Enormously Expensive Experience.
leadPara: IT is the opinion of George B. Ford, director of the investigations of the Heights of Buildings Commission, city planning expert, student of municipal efficiency and conditions governing real estate in this country and Europe, who, for reasons which I am not at liberty to state, is likely soon to be better known to the general public than he now is, that New York sadly needs to stabilize its real estate values.

headline: CHATTER FROM HERE AND THERE; Daughters of Texas Present Flag to Battleship, and Plan Ball -- Mrs. Paterno Gives a Blossom Tea -- Many Preparing to Open Summer Houses.
leadPara: ALL a Norfolk girl is supposed to have for a dowry is a pair of oyster tongs and a naval register," said Capt. Grant of the battleship Texas to an audience of Texas women last Wednesday. "and one day, years ago, as I was walking along a street in Norfolk a door opened and out came a pair of oyster tongs.

headline: CHINESE WOMEN ARE PROGRESSING FAST
leadPara: TEN years ago the Chinese woman suffered from unkindness, from ignorance, and sometimes from brutality. To-day she is given equal franchise with me. Ten years ago practically all of the Chinese women lived under the discord-hatching matriarchal system, where the primary wife, however ignorant and unreasonable, held unquestioned sway over secondary wives, daughters-in-law, daughters, and slave girls.

headline: Article 1 -- No Title
leadPara: CHICAGO, May 12. -- According to Medill McCormick of this city, leader of the Progressive Party In this State and now war correspondent in Mexico, Private Samuel Parks, whose singular disappearance from the American lines outside of Vera Cruz has been a matter of considerable conjecture and apprehension, was executed on Friday morning last by order of the commandant of the Mexican Federal post at Tejeria. and his body was burned.
abstract: reports execution of Private Parks to Brig. Gen. Funston

headline: LEGISLATIVE FIGHT SENT TO CONFERENCE; Senate Amends Assembly Bill So As to Provide Funds for Two Disputed Departments.
leadPara: ALBANY, May 12. -- The Democratic Senate and the Republican Assembly tonight agreed to disagree on appropriations and appointed a conference committee, which will meet at 10 o'clock tomorrow forenoon and try to adjust the differences. The Republicans will have six of the ten members composing the committee. The findings of the committee, however, are not binding in Senate or Assembly.
abstract: Passes on financial bills, amendments defeated to pay $12,000 salary to John H. Delaney for next fiscal year and statutory salaries for Fire Marshal's office

headline: ROOSEVELT LAWYER IN RACE; Pound, of Libel Suit Fame, to Run for Governor in Michigan.
abstract: James Pound is Progressive candidate for nomination for Governor

headline: TRYING GUARDSMEN ON MURDER CHARGE; Arson and Larceny Also Alleged Against 39 in Colorado Strike Court-Martial.
leadPara: DENVER, May 13. -- The death pit at the Ludlow tent colony, where the charred bodies of two women and eleven children were found on the morning following the battle of April 20, was described in minute detail to-day by witnesses before the court-martial assembled at the Rifle Range near Golden. While formal charges are pending against only thirty-nine officers and men, 100 members of the State militia are involved.
abstract: court-martial assembles; guardsmen charged with murder, arson, and larceny; Maj. Hamrock on trial first; three militia witnesses exonerate him from blame for tent horror

headline: FACTION IN SENATE OPPOSING WARBURG; La Follette, Cummins, Borah, and Others Object to Putting Him on Reserve Board.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, May 13. -- There were indications to-day of opposition in the Senate to the appointment of Paul M. Warburg of New York and Harry A. Wheeler of Chicago as members of the Federal Reserve Board. While Mr. Warburg has accepted the tender of a place on the board, it is said that Mr. Wheeler has not yet notified the President that he will serve.
abstract: opposed by faction in Senate

headline: FIRED ON TENT COLONY.; But State Troops Did It to Repel Strikers' Attack, Witnesses Say.
leadPara: DENVER, May 14. -- The State militia fired directly into the tents at Ludlow where subsequently two women and eleven children were suffocated in a pit on April 20, according to the admission made to-day by First Lieut. Maurice C. Bigelow, a witness before the court martial at Golden.
abstract: Robinson resolution introduced; Repr. Thomas introduces resolution asking Pres. Wilson to appoint Federal peace commission

headline: ADMITS MILITIAMEN KILLED PRISONERS; Colorado Guardsman Describes the Shooting of Tikas, Strike Leader, and Two Others.
leadPara: DENVER, Col., May 15. -- Sergeant Patrick N. Cullom, Company B, Second Infantry, Colorado National Guard, testified to-day before the military court martial that Louis Tikas, leader of the Greek strikers at Ludlow, and two other prisoners were shot and killed by soldiers when they tried to escape during the battle in which two women and eleven children were killed.
abstract: testifiesat investigation of Col. strike war

headline: To-morrow's Sunday Times.
leadPara: What is the present status of the trusts under the law? What need is there for further legislation? The Sherman law was passed nearly a quarter of a century ago, and since then it has been interpreted and made workable by a progressive series of Supreme Court decisions. What have these decisions done to the law?

headline: IMPROVING THE BASEMENT STORE; Things Done to Make Downstairs Attractive to Customers in the Big Shops.
leadPara: " He's doing the cellar trick now," or "they're letting the youngster struggle belowstairs," often used to be said of the superannuated and the young and inexperienced man, respectively, after he had been relegated to the "under-price section" to try his hand at minor merchandising.

AT FALL RIVER MILLS.; Better Feeling Shown, Though Buying Is Still Small.
leadPara: FALL RIVER, Mass., May 16. -- While conditions in the cotton goods markets have changed but little this week, still there is a better feeling manifest, and the sentiment is good. Buyers have shown themselves as being quite content to buy in small lots, and no desire has been shown to make their purchases larger, it being stated that, with the downward tendency in prices, goods may be had later at even lower prices.

headline: WILSON CONDEMNS FOREIGN ALLIANCES; Declaration at Barry Unveiling Taken to Bear on Pacification of Mexico.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Men and women of Irish birth and descent from all over the country joined with the President of the United States, members of the Senate and the House of Representatives, and other dignitaries this afternoon in the ceremonies attending the unveiling of the statue erected to the memory of Commodore John Barry, "the father of the American Navy."
abstract: speaks at unveiling of statue to Commodore John Barry

headline: WILSON TICKET FAVORED.; Expected to Win in Pennsylvania Primary To-morrow.
leadPara: PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- What is regarded as the most important primary election in the history of Pennsylvania and one which is expected to engage the attention of the entire country in view of the prominence of the candidates and the issues at stake will be held next TueSday.
abstract: Wilson ticket favored

headline: BEVERIDGE ATTACKS WILSON; He Says Intervention Is the Only Mean for Pacifying Mexico.
leadPara: INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 18. -- In a speech before the Progressive Club of Indiana to-night, Albert J. Beveridge, candidate for United States Senator, attacked the policy of President Wilson in the Mexican situation, and indicated that he regarded intervention as the only course left to pacify Mexico.
abstract: found dead, victim of foul play

headline: MAKE SWEEPING CLAIMS.; All Factions Seemingly Confident on Eve of Keystone Primary.
abstract: all factions confident of victory

headline: FORGET THE 'SYSTEM' IS BRUERE'S ADVICE; Says Police Opportunity Is in the Field of Social Service.
leadPara: City Chamberlain Bruere, speaking before a body of Progressives at Terrace Garden last night, outlined some of the problems that he said Mayor Mitchel expects to solve during the present administration. Taking up police matters, Mr. Bruere said that what was needed was for the members of the force to forget about the existence of a "system" and to turn their attention to the working out of the real problems of the department.
abstract: meeting addressed by City Chamberlain Brucre

headline: ROOSEVELT, ILL, DUE ON THE AIDAN TO-DAY; Tug to Meet Him at Quarantine and Take Him by Water to Oyster Bay.
leadPara: W. Emlen Roosevelt received a wireless message from Theodore Roosevelt at 8 o'clock last night informing him that the Booth Line steamship Aidan was 300 miles south of Sandy Hook at noon yesterday and the Captain expected to reach Quarantine about 4 o'clock this afternoon.
abstract: to arrive on Aidan, Oyster Bay to celebrate

headline: PALMER-M'CORMICK VICTORY; Administration Ticket Wins in Pennsylvania -- Penrose Triumphs Also.
leadPara: PHILADELPHIA, May 19. -- Penrose and Brumbaugh, the organization Republican candidates for nomination for United States Senator and Governor of Pennsylvania respectively, swept the State in today's primaries, the former by from 100,000 to 125,000 majority and the latter by a majority far in excess of these figures, while Palmer for Senator and McCormick for Governor on the Democratic ticket, supported by the Wilson Administration, won the nominations.
abstract: wins in Penn. primaries

headline: "THE VOICE OF THE PEOPLE."
leadPara: The direct primary had its first trial in Pennsylvania on Tuesday. The voice of the people, unmuffled and undiverted by the machine, made itself heard. No convention, no caucus, no mandate of the bosses was, in law and in theory, allowed to interfere with the popular choice.
abstract: results of primary law, editorial

headline: ROOSEVELT SEES MOOSE LEADERS; Colonel May Make Countrywide Campaign Tour on Return from Spain.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, May 20. -- The situation confronting the Progressive Party was the principal topic of discussion at Sagamore Hill to-day. Col. Roosevelt scarcely had time to unpack his trunks before George W. Perkins, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the National Committee, arrived at the Hill by automobile.
abstract: sees Progressive leaders to make campaign tour on return from Spain

headline: SONS AS CITIZENS.; Organized School Democracies Train Them Properly.
abstract: Oragnized school democracies praised in letter by Frank Kiernan

headline: WHAT THEY TOLD HIM.
leadPara: There is no authoritative statement of what Mr. ROOSEVELT'S comrades and political advisors told him at Sagamore Hill, but any one who has watched the currents of political opinion and sentiment, such as they have been, since the explorer's departure for his final "great physical effort," can make a guess more than plausible as to the facts that were presented for his reflection.
abstract: editorial

headline: NEIGHBORS TURN OUT TO GREET COLONEL; Children of Oyster Bay Welcome Roosevelt with a Song and He Has 'Bulliest Time of His Life.'
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 21. -- To use his own words, Col. Roosevelt had the "bulliest time of his life" today. Although he refused to consent to any public demonstration in New York upon his return from South America, the Colonel agreed to attend the celebration planned by the townsfolk of this place in his honor.
abstract: Celebration to greet Col. Theodore Roosevelt, address of welcome by Robert F. Duvall, Colonel's reply

headline: BUSINESS WORLD
leadPara: Advance business booked by the ostrich feather manufacturers would seem to indicate the return to popularity of feathers in the Fall. The demand has centered for the most part on French plumes and headtips. Colors, such as blues, greens and wistarias have been well favored.
abstract: Printcloth buying active

headline: HELP AGAINST RUSSIA.; Baltic Provinces Look to Western Civilization to Save Them.
leadPara: To me and, no doubt, to a vast number of your admiring friends the periodically appearing articles on Russia are of the utmost interest. If you take into consideration that we, exiles and refugees from around the Baltic coast, for many reasons have to hide our identity, you will understand the appreciation that rises from a beating heart when the ruthless reign of stupidity is shown up in so illuminating a light.
abstract: letter from Frustra Vocavi

headline: PINCHOT WILL WIN, THE COLONEL HEARS; Leader Flinn Tells Roosevelt Progressives Will Elect Senator from Pennsylvania.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 22. -- There was a steady stream of Progressive politicians up Sagamore Hill today. They discussed the political situation with Col. Roosevelt for many hours and from many viewpoints. William Flinn, National Committeeman from Pennsylvania and leader of the Progressive party there, who brought the State into line for the Progressives in 1912, dined with the Colonel tonight with Gifford Pinchot, the Progressive candidate for United States Senator in Pennsylvania.
abstract: discusses Progressive Party in N. Y. with Col. Roosevelt

headline: DESIGNER OF VATERLAND'S HULL DESCRIBES BIGGEST SHIP; Dr. Ernst Foerster Tells of Unique Funnel Arrangement, Cruiser Stern, and Other Notable Features -- Says Ships Could Be Built Much Larger, but Harbor Accommodation Is Lacking Here and Abroad.
leadPara: DR. ERNST FOERSTER, naval architect of the Hamburg-American Line and the designer of the hull and steel work of the Vaterland, in an interview for THE NEW YORK TIMES has described what he considers the chief features, from the construction viewpoint, of the world's biggest ship.

headline: WHEN THE RASH FALL OUT.
leadPara: It is reported from Washington that there is a fine three-cornered fight on over the exemption of laboring men and farmers from the penalties of any and all anti-trust laws. There is a qualified exemption for their combinations in restraint of trade in the pending Clayton bill, and to this it is understood that the President has given his somewhat reluctant assent.

headline: EX-PRESIDENT TAFT DISCUSSES ATTACKS ON THE COURTS; In His Second Article on the Trust Decisions He Writes of "Judge-Made Law" and Declares That the Supreme Court, "Attacked with III-Disguised Vituperation from Jefferson to Roosevelt," Has Been Responsive to Public Opinion -- Criticisms "Born of Ignorance or Demagogy."
SOCIETY BRIDES TO REIGN IN TOWN AND COUNTRY
leadPara: MISS HELEN APPLETON, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Ross "Appleton, and Charles A. Read, Jr., of Boston, are to be married on Wednesday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. 146 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn. Only relatives are to witness the ceremony, which is to be performed at 4 o'clock, but the reception following will be a large one. Miss Marie Appleton is to be her sister's only attendant.

headline: FELIX DIAZ WANTS AN OPEN ELECTION; Suggests That Envoys Consult All Mexican Parties in Picking a Provisional President.
leadPara: TORONTO, Ontario, May 23. -- Gen. Felix Diaz, who is stopping here, said today that he heartily approved of the peace congress at Niagara Falls. headline: NOBODY CAN INDUCE THE COLONEL TO RUN; Won't Be Considered for Governor, He Says; It's Absurd, and This Is His Third Denial.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 24. -- The report that Col. Roosevelt would run for Governor on the Progressive ticket next Fall was settled by the Colonel himself today. He said that he would not be a candidate and that no one could induce him to think of such a thing. He called the report absurd, and asserted that his candidacy was not being considered at the conferences at Sagamore Hill.

headline: ROOSEVELT SHOWS HIS RIVER ON MAP; "We Put It There," He Says, Defying Critics Before the Geographic Society. SPENDS A VERY BUSY DAY Tells Progressives in Capital That He Will Lead Party's Fight This Fall. CALLS ON THE PRESIDENT Spends Half an Hour in Social Talk -- Inspects His African Trophies in the Museum.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, May 27. -- Col. Theodore Roosevelt, after one of the busiest days of his busy life, left Washington for New York at 12:15 o'clock this morning. He arrived about 3 o'clock yesterday, (Tuesday) afternoon in the National Capital, where for seven years he occupied the Presidency.

headline: COLONEL'S BUSY AFTERNOON.; First Inspects His African Specimens, Then Visits White House.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Col. Roosevelt reached Washington this afternoon soon after 3 o'clock as the guest of the National Geographic Society to tell its members in a lecture of his experiences in the interior of South America and of his discovery of "the River of Doubt." He was accompanied from New York by O.K. Davis, Secretary of the National Progressive Committee, and Congressman Hinebaugh of Illinois, Chairman of the Progressive Congressional Committee.

headline: ROOSEVELT READY TO ENTER CAMPAIGN; Will Lead His Party on the Fight This Fall, He Tells Congressman.

headline: SPELLACY DIVERTS BOLT.; Fisher Democrats in Connecticut Induced to Stay In the Party.

headline: COLONEL READY FOR TRIP.; Refuses to See Many Political Callers and Has Good Rest.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., June 29. -- Col. Roosevelt refused to see several political visitors who came to Sagamore Hill today that he might obtain a complete rest in preparation for his trip to Pittsburgh tomorrow. It is understood that some of the visitors were anxious to reopen the question of the Colonel's running for Governor despite his impaired health, but he did not want to hear their pleas.

headline: ROOSEVELT'S BID FOR UNION.
leadPara: There was not a word of attack upon the Republican Party in Col. ROOSEVELT'S Pittsburgh speech. He did attack Senator PENROSE, but the speech was such as might be made by any Republican in good standing who disapproved of Penroseism; in fact, such speeches have frequently been made by just such men without impairing their Republican standing.
abstract: editorial

headline: TO MAKE SENATE PASS TRUST BILLS; Democrats in Conference Today Will Resolve to Continue Session Till Work Is Finished.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Democratic Senators have been called to meet in conference at 4 o'clock tomorrow afternoon to pass a resolution announcing that the Senate will continue in session until the trust programme, as outlined by President Wilson, is disposed of. But no effort will be made to bind Senators to the measures comprising the programme, according to the information obtainable today.
abstract: quotes Pres. Wilson's campaign speech against trade commission legislation

headline: JUDGE GARY SEES GOOD TIMES AHEAD; But Admits Business Is Bad Now, Prices Low, and Wage Reductions Are Probable.
leadPara: Judge Elbert H. Gary, Chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, looks for an improvement in business this Fall. He is sailing on the Aquitania today for his annual vacation in Europe. He embodied his estimate of an early recovery in trade in a talk on conditions delivered to the Presidents of the Steel Corporation's subsidiary companies last Thursday.
abstract: Judge Gary prophesies improvement

headline: COLONEL ASSAILS WILSON POLICIES; But He Refrains from Antagonism of Republican Party in Pittsburgh Speech.
leadPara: PITTSBURGH, June 30. -- The Pennsylvania Progressives gave Col. Roosevelt a welcome tonight which must have reminded hi mof 1912, when he was a candidate for President. Perhaps some of the enthusiasm which always marks the culmination of a race for office was missing, but there could be no doubting that Col. Roosevelt had retained his popularity in this section of the State.
abstract: Roosevelt addresses immense audience in Pittsburgh, assails Wilson policies and attacks bosses Barnes and Penrose, Progressive League entertains him at luncheon

headline: WADSWORTH LEADS IN U.S. SENATE RACE; Chairman Barnes Voices Republican Regret at Elihu Root's Retirement.
leadPara: While in some quarters there was a disposition not to regard as final the action of United States Senator Elihu Root in definitely declining to become a candidate for re-election, Republican State Chairman William Barnes and other Republican leaders in close touch with Senator Root yesterday seemed to take it for granted that the party must look elsewhere for a candidate for United States Senator.

headline: ROOSEVELT'S THROAT IS MENDING FAST; Dr. Curtis Tells Him Six Weeks' Rest Will Give Him Full Vocal Power.
leadPara: The effort to induce Col. Roosevelt to run as the Progressive candidate for Governor was renewed yesterday as soon as the Colonel returned from Pittsburgh. A delegation of twenty-five Democrats and Republicans from the Thirty-first Assembly District was introduced to the Colonel while he was visiting the American Museum of Natural History by Assemblyman Michael Schaap.
abstract: Delegation of Democrats and Republicans see Roosevelt and urge him to run

headline: MITCHEL AND COLONEL CONFER; Talk State Politics, but Mayor Says He's No Candidate.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 2. -- Mayor John Purroy Mitchel of New York was the guest of Col. Roosevelt at Sagamore Hill tonight, and upon leaving to return to his home in Manhattan he admitted that "in a general way" State politics was discussed. He was asked if his visit was to be taken as an indication that he would, under any circumstances, throw his support to a sort of ProgressiveFusion or anti-boss ticket.
abstract: confers with Roosevelt, talks State politics, but says he is no candidate

headline: CALLS ON BARNES TO QUIT.; Editorial Barring Whitman Puzzles Followers of Aldridge.
abstract: editorial in the Evening Times of Rochester barring Whitman puzzles followers of George W. Adridge, resignation of Barnes asked for

headline: NO MORE FOR ROOSEVELT.; Republican Party Will Not Again Accept Him as a Leader.
leadPara: I read your editorial article entitled "Roosevelt's Bid for Union" with deep interest. You have correctly analyzed his motives and interpreted his speech at Pittsburgh, but Roosevelt will fail in his attempt to unite the Republican and Progressive Parties and become the leader of both.
abstract: letter from Charles H. Betts

headline: PLANS FUSION IN THE STATE.; Colonel Seeks an Independent Democrat to Head Ticket.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 3. -- There was a persistent report here today, following the visit of Mayor Mitchel last night, that Col. Roosevelt, defeated in his hope of arranging some sort of a working agreement with the anti-Barnes Republicans, was seeking escape from the nomination of a straight Progressive ticket in this State next Fall by laying plans for a Fusion or anti-boss campaign.

headline: ROOSEVELT'S TIME ALL FOR POLITICS; QUITS AS EDITOR; Resigns from The Outlook Staff to Labor for Progressive Platform of 1912.
leadPara: Col. Roosevelt has resigned his place as contributing editor of The Outlook in order to devote all his time to politics. This announcement will be made in The Outlook's next issue together with the correspondence between Col. Roosevelt and Dr. Lyman Abbott.
abstract: in conference with Mayor Mitchel

headline: SEES A GOOD FUTURE FOR CLAFLIN HOUSE; If Modernized It Will Be Profitable in a Restricted Territory, The Economist Says.
leadPara: Judge Hand signed an order in the United States District Court yesterday authorizing J.B. Martindale and Frederic A. Juilliard, receivers for the H.B. Claflin Company, to waive protest of the notes indorsed by it. The notes number about 8,000 and aggregate about $30,000,000. If protested, the notaries' fees would amount to about $16,000, which will be saved to the creditors by Judge Hand's order.
abstract: business being carried on as usual, methods to be modernized, comment of Dry Goods Economist

headline: Obituary 1 -- No Title
abstract: death and career

headline: M'CAHEY PILOTS THREE WINNERS; Blue Thistle Makes a "Killing" in the Fourth Race at Aqueduct Track.
leadPara: In all the races in which they rode at the Aqueduct track yesterday, McCahey and Marco got into the money. McCahey started off by winning the first three races, in each of which Marco rode the horse that finished third. McCahey had no mount in the fourth race, but Marco again ran third.
abstract: Blue Thistle wins, summaries, entries

headline: COLONEL UNDER FIRE OF HIGH TARIFF MAN; Joseph R. Grundy Accuses Roosevelt of Being a Real Enemy of Protection.
leadPara: PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- " Theodore Roosevelt sold out American labor to Germany., He is an enemy to the Republican policy of protection and his charge that the PaYne-Aldrich Tariff bill was/prepared with ' reckless haste' is a probf of mendacity."

headline: SPORTS AT GREENWICH.; Yachting, Golf, and Tennis Galore at Connecticut Resort.
leadPara: GREENWICH, Conn., July 4. -- This place is gay with flags and hunting today, and a long list of entertainments is under way at the various hotels and clubs. "Pomander Walk," by the Frank Lea Short Dramatic Company was played on the lawn of the Edgewood Club in the afternoon. In the evening at the same place "The Romancers,'' by Edmond Rostand, was produced in the open air.

headline: ABC POWERS AND U.S. CAN AVERT YELLOW PERIL, SAYS YALE AUTHORITY; Prof. Hiram Bingham Declares That Our New Policy in Conjunction with Leading South American Nations Will Prevent Oriental Aggression.
leadPara: NO matter what view the average citizen takes of the protracted session of the ABC mediators at Niagara, Hiram Bingham, Assistant Professor of Latin-American History at Yale University, believes the meeting means the initiation of a policy that will be of inestimable value to both North and South America.

headline: PLATFORM MAKERS TO BEGIN WORK NOW; Senator Root with 25 on Committee Will Make Republican Planks.
leadPara: Special committees will begin the work of constructing tentative Democratic and Republican State platforms in a few days. The plans and programme for the campaign of the three leading parties have already been worked out in their main details.

headline: NATIONAL ISSUES TO CLOUD CAMPAIGN; Barnes and Osborn Both Say State Issues Will Not Stand Alone.
leadPara: No matter what effort may be made by the Progressives to run their campaign in this State on State issues solely, the fact that a United States Senator and members of the House of Representatives are to be elected this Fall is likely to bring national issues prominently into the campaign.

headline: THE BALKAN WAR; Important Results for the Peace Movement Gained Through the International Commission
leadPara: HISTORY written to serve a purpose is at best a difficult task, and may well prove relatively a thankless one. When, however, the purpose is lofty and is frankly avowed, and when the work is that of a group of able and devoted publicists, of various lands and of international repute, the worst of the obstacles are avoided, and the result merits the candid and careful attention of the public.

headline: PLEAS FOR IDEALS MARK A SANE 4TH; Mayor Urges Citizens to Join the War Upon Bosses and Corrupt Politics.
leadPara: The 138th anniversary of American independence was celebrated in New York yesterday in a safer and saner way than has been attempted since Mayor Gaynor started the movement for New York four years ago.
abstract: addresses Knights of Columbus Fourth of July celebration, talks of ships

headline: PERKINS IS HOPEFUL.; Roosevelt May Be Forced Into Primaries for Governor, He Writes.

abstract: Roosevelt asked for his opinion on subject by Dr. Daniel Hoffman Martin

headline: COLONEL PLANS TO BREAK SOLID SOUTH; Will Go to Louisiana, Where He Hears Progressives Have a Good Chance to Win.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 5. -- For the first time in many years the gates which were erected to guard the entrance to the private road leading to Sagamore Hill, were closed today. The padlock had long been missing and a stout piece of rope was used to replace it.
abstract: will go to La., where Progressives have a good chance to win

headline: WASHINGTON SET TO INVADE NEWPORT; Society Seeks New Field This Summer After a Decrease in Ballroom Attendance.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, July 6. -- "On to Newport!" is the cry of Washington's smart set. A new declaration of independence has been declared on Sheridan Circle and the outlying district of Upper Sixteenth Street, where the Winter colony of the National Capital has built its largest and finest homes.

headline: COLORADO APPEALS TO THE COLONEL; Will See Progressive Chairman Dodge, Who Wants Him to Campaign There.
abstract: Roosevelt buttons advocating him as Gov. to be distributed through State, to be at home on Wednesday at N. Y. C. headquarters

headline: BORAH DENOUNCES NICARAGUA TREATY; Founded on "Deception, Misrepresentation Fraud, Tyranny, and Corruption," He Says.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The most savage criticism or the proposed Nicaraguan treaty yet heard in the Senate came today from Mr. Borah of Idaho one of the most prominent members of the Committee on Foreign Relations, who, as a progressive Republican, has hopes of welding the two Republican factions together to support his Presidential aspirations in 1916.
abstract: is surprised at Sen. Borah's demand for public hearings on Nicaragua treaty

headline: ROOSEVELT COMING TO LISTEN.; Many Progressives Will Ask Him Just What to Do in State.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 7. -- Col. Roosevelt received word today that Progressive Party leaders from many sections of the State were hurrying to New York to confer with him on the State situation when he goes to national headquarters in the Forty-second Street Building tomorrow.

headline: DESERT TO PROGRESSIVES.; Louisiana Democratic Committee Loses Six of Its Members.

headline: ROOSEVELT 'AT HOME' IN POLITICS TODAY; Up-Staters at the Progressive Headquarters Will Urge Him to Run.
leadPara: Col. Roosevelt's first "at home" at the headquarters of the Progressive National Committee in the Forty-second Street Building today promises to be lively and eventful. The Progressive leaders, who have not by any means abandoned hope that Col. Roosevelt will run for Governor, either on the Progressive ticket or as a Fusion candidate, will take advantage of the Colonel's first appearance at headquarters to bring strong pressure to bear on him.
abstract: delegation of Republicans and Democrats from Rochester to urge Roosevelt to run for Gov.

headline: HE IS NEVER CALLED "POP."
leadPara: The gentleman who has announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Congress against JOSEPH G. CANNON says he does so because the ex-Speaker is no longer in touch "with the younger element in his district." If he means that Uncle JOE is not a Progressive, a radical, a reformer, or an uplifter he is right.
abstract: editorial

headline: IOWA PROGRESSIVES GO DRY.; After Long Fight Their State Convention Votes for Prohibition.
abstract: Progressives vote for prohibition at State convention

headline: FUSION UP TO DATE.
leadPara: It is rather remarkable that, with all the talk about fusion with the Republicans which has been heard in the Progressive camp, the only fusions so far accomplished have been with the Democrats. In Utah there was a complete fusion between the Democrats and Progressives.
abstract: editorial

headline: ROFRANO, "WITH A PUNCH."; Fetherston Praises His Deputy as "One Who Can Put Things Over."
leadPara: Michael A. Rofrano, recently appointed First Deputy Street Cleaning Commissioner by Mayor Mitchel, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner of the Italian National Club in its home at 117 West Forty-eighth Street. More than 300 members of the club and their guests applauded the several speakers, among them Magistrate J.J.
abstract: praises Rofrano at dinner of Italian National Club

headline: ROOSEVELT, URGED TO RUN, IS SILENT; Meets Progressives at National Headquarters and Listens to Pleas.

headline: MITCHEL BELIEVES FUSION IS POSSIBLE; But Mayor Says the City Administration Has No Candidate.
leadPara: Mayor Mitchel, as Mayor, does not intend to dabble into the political situation this Fall. As an individual, however, he expects to express his opinion on political matters from time to time. Mr. Mitchel believes that a fusion of independent Democrats and Progressives is most difficult and improbable, but still a political possibility.
abstract: was asked by suffragettes to name a suffragist on committee to write Republican platform

headline: A CALL FROM MACEDONIA.
leadPara: That a number of Progressives from other States should have come to New York to urge Col. ROOSEVELT not to yield to those who want him to run for Governor is not to be wondered at. The arguments they presented must have been strong. It would profit him nothing to poll a large vote in this State while his party went to ruin in every other State.

headline: SAYS COLONEL CAN'T RUN.; Perkins Says He Should Not Be Forced Into State Race.
leadPara: ELMIRA, N.Y., July 10. -- At a banquet of the Progressives of this Congressional District here tonight, George W. Perkins, Chairman of the National Executive Committee of the party, said that Col. Roosevelt's work was of national scope and that he should not be forced into a State Campaign as a candidate for Governor.

headline: PANAMA BROADSIDE BY ROOSEVELT SOON; Colonel Consults with Ex-Secretary Bishop of the Commission.

He had as his guest at dinner tonight Joseph B. Bishop, who was secretary of the Panama Canal, Commission under Roosevelt.
abstract: Roosevelt refuses to discuss "Sulzer danger," Perkins says he should not be forced into Gubernatorial race

headline: HINMAN IS NOT TO RUN FOR GOVERNOR; Calder Denies Making Any Deal with Southern Tier Leader.
leadPara: Word reached Republican leaders in this city yesterday that ex-Senator Harvey D. Hinman, of Binghamton, would not be a candidate in the primaries this fall for either the Gubernatorial nomination or the nomination for United States Senator to succeed Elihu Root. With Mr. Hinman out of the way as a candidate for Governor the anti-Barnes men will find it easier to support Whitman.

leadPara: OYSTER BAY, July 11. -- When John McGrath, now political secretary to Col. Roosevelt, settled down in Oyster Bay for the Summer, George W. Perkins, Chairman of the National Executive Committee supplied him with a motor cycle for trips between the hotel and Sagamore Hill.

headline: COLONEL UNWILLING TO SAY YES OR NO; New Yorkers Demand That Roosevelt Run and Leaders In Other States Object.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, July 11. -- Developments which have greatly encouraged those who want Col. Roosevelt to run for Governor have served also to arouse leaders in other parts of the country, who are opposed to the Colonel taking such a step.

headline: A VANISHING PARTY.
leadPara: In North Dakota the Progressive Party failed to nominate a State ticket because it had fallen short of the number of votes necessary to secure a place on the official ballot. To nominate a candidate, it is necessary, under the law, that a party must have at least 25 per cent. of the vote cast for its candidate at the last previous election, and the North Dakota Progressives could get only 2,430 votes.
abstract: A vanishing party, editorial

headline: Southern Railway.
leadPara: The railroads in the Southeastern territory, in which Southern Railway Company operates, have not felt the pinch of the business depression during the past year as acutely as the railroads north of the Potomac and Ohio Rivers.

headline: WHITMAN LETTER HE NEVER WROTE; Progressives Start Rumor of a Repudiation of Chairman Barnes. "IT DOES NOT EXIST" District Attorney Promptly Denies That Charles H. Duell, Jr., or Any One Else Has It.
leadPara: Rumors from Progressive sources in this city were circulated last night to the effect that the Whitman Non-Partisan League, of which Charles H. Duell, Jr., is the head, had in its possession a letter written some time last month by Charles S. Whitman to the league, in which the District Attorney denied any form of allegiance to any political boss, and singled out William Barnes as one from whose influence he was especially free.

Whitman had written a letter to the Whitman Non-Partisan League, in which he repudiated William Barnes, Jr., the Chairman of the Republican State Committee, as an objectionable boss, were received with great interest today at Oyster Bay.

Jones of Chicago to the Federal Reserve Board was taken up indirectly on the floor of the Senate in secret session.

leadPara: OTTAWA, Ill., July 15. -- Col. Roosevelt will not be the Republican candidate for President in 1916, but will head the Progressive ticket if he lives, according to W.H. Hinebaugh, Chairman of the Progressive Congressional Committee, in an address here today.

headline: ROOSEVELT TALKS POLITICS TO WOMEN; Tells Female Progressives at Colony Club Luncheon That He Is with Them.

headline: ROOSEVELT DOOMED IN 1916, SAYS BRYAN; Wilson's Progressiveness Sealed the Colonel's Fate, Nebraskan Writes in The Commoner.
leadPara: LINCOLN, Neb., July 16. -- William J. Bryan tomorrow in a signed editorial in his Commoner, will defend the Wilson Administration against the attack of Theodore Roosevelt. Following his defense, he says that while Mr. Roosevelt may add to the gayety of the campaign, he will not weaken the President.
abstract: Sec. Bryan will defend Wilson against his attacks in editorial in The Commoner

headline: BULL MOOSE TALK OF HENNESSY NOW; Sulzer Investigator Talks with Roosevelt and Is at Once Talked Of for Governor.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 16. -- John A. Hennessy, who, by his fiery speeches against Tammany Hall, did much to elect the Fusion ticket in the last Mayoralty campaign in New York, is being considered seriously by the Progressives as the man to head the fight in New York State this Fall.
abstract: John A. Hennessy talked of as candidate on fusion ticket with Progressives

headline: WHITMAN DISOWNS THE 'C.S.W.' DRAFT; Disapproved It, F. S. Tanner Says, When Duell Submitted It.
leadPara: In a formal statement made public last night, District Attorney Charles S. Whitman made sweeping denial of the allegation that he was the author of a letter draft initialed "C.S.W." which Col. Roosevelt gave to the newspapers on Wednesday night at Oyster Bay, accompanied by another broadside against Mr. Whitman, who happens to be the most formidable rival of the Progressives for the Governorship.

headline: WHITMAN URGED HIM ON, DUELL DECLARES; Says District Attorney Saw "Letter of Doubt" and Approved It.

headline: SULZER HITS ROOSEVELT.; Says the Colonel Is Playing Into C. F. Murphy's Hands.
leadPara: Assemblyman William Sulzer announced yesterday that even consideration or Col. Theodore Roosevelt would not keep him out of the Progressive primaries as a candidate for the Gubernatorial nomination. This is a complete change of front on the part of Mr. Sulzer, who a few days ago declared that solicitude for the Colonel so far had kept him from going after the Progressive nomination for Governor.
abstract: Sulzer announces his candidacy

headline: HIS PRIVATE GRAVEYARD.
leadPara: It seems likely that the name of JOHN A. HENNESSY is put forward as a Progressive candidate for Governor not with any intention of nominating him, but for the purpose of killing off the Sulzer boom. The movement for SULZER in the Bull Moose Party has grown to such a height that it is seriously disturbing the Progressive leaders, who know that if he should carry the primaries their party would be split wide open.
abstract: His private graveyard, editorial

headline: MODERN ROAD BUILDING.; Plan by Which Each Step Takes Care of Present and Future.
leadPara: Highway improvement, like the growth of population, should be progressive, argues the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce. Each stage should be suited to the requirements of its period. This contem plates, first, the proper locating, grading and drainage of the sub-base, which are essential to any good road.

headline: FEDERAL PATRONAGE IN WAR ON MURPHY; Forty Postmasters to be Named in This State by Wilson Before the Primaries.
leadPara: The most cheering tidings that have come to the anti-Murphy Democrats since the inauguration of President Wilson came yesterday in the form of an authoritative report that forty Post-masterships in President's Wilson's gift would be filled prior to the primaries, and that each of these offices would go to a decided anti-Murphy and anti-organization Democrat.

headline: MR. WHITMAN'S BLUNDER.
THINKS WHITMAN IS CHECKED.; Col. Roosevelt Believes He Will Lose in Both Primaries.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.J., July 19. -- Col. Roosevelt refused today to make any further comment in reply to the statements issued by District Attorney Whitman. The Colonel feels that Mr. Whitman's replies to his charges were entirely inadequate, and that other political leaders and the voters are satisfied that Mr. Whitman has been playing a double game in attempting to get the Progressive support and not openly offend Republican State Chairman Barnes.
abstract: thinks Whitman is checkmated

headline: WANTS ASSEMBLY OF BUSINESS MEN; Roosevelt Is Asked to Head a Ticket of General Excellence.
leadPara: A proposition has been made to Col. Roosevelt by several members of the Progressive Party that he run for Governor on a ticket to be made up, as much as possible, of business men who would be willing to serve the State, not for what they can get out of it, but for the advantage of the ordinary citizen.
abstract: plan urged by George H. Payne for Assembly of business men headed by Roosevelt as Gov.

headline: HINMAN TO HEAD FUSION, LATEST PLAN; Roosevelt Believed to Have Decided Not to Run for Governor.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 20. -- Developments in the political situation as viewed here all indicate that Col. Theodore Roosevelt has decided definitely not to run as the candidate of the Progressive Party for Governor of New York State.
abstract: Stephen C. Clark may be offered nomination

headline: OSBORN MET APATHY IN UP-STATE TRIP; No Democratic Candidates Except for Governor, Chairman Says.
leadPara: William Church Osborn, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, returned yesterday from a trip up-State, where he went to make a careful examination of the political situation. He said he found a great deal of apathy among the Democrats, especially in Republican counties.
abstract: Robert Ludlow Fowler mentioned as possible candidate

headline: THE NEW YORK CAMPAIGN.
leadPara: Last Fall one of the greatest popular votes that ever was cast against Tammany produced a monumental majority for Mayor MITCHEL. When he was nominated there were doubt, discouragement, and disaffection among the anti-Tammany voters, and at first his chances seemed to be slight.

headline: ROOSEVELT SAYS HE'S PLEASED; Fusion Ticket Is Planned and Colonel Will Stump State. HINMAN TO RUN AS ANTI-BARNES
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 21. -- The statement issued in Binghamton tonight by ex-Senator Harvey D. Hinman, in which he openly repudiated Barnes, ended all doubt here that Col. Roosevelt will do everything in his power to throw the indorsement of the Progressive Party in New York State to the Broome County RepubLican.

headline: HINMAN TO RUN AS ANTI-BARNES; Roosevelt's Fusion Candidate Will Enter Republican Primaries for Governor.
leadPara: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 21. -- ExSenator Harvey D. Hinman tonight declared himself a candidate for Governor in thc coming Republican primaries, on a platform against the leadership of State Chairman William Barnes, and declared "that the time has come for the destruction of thc bi-partisan system in this State."
abstract: says he's pleased with Hinman running for Gov. as anti-Barnes candidate, plans a fusion

headline: MR. HINMAN'S CHALLENGE.
leadPara: Mr. HINMAN'S pithy and pungent declaration of his candidacy for Governor on an anti-machine platform insures a real fight at the Republican primaries. It is evident that it will be between him and Mr. WHITMAN, who will probably have the support of the Barnes organization.
abstract: editorial

headline: ROOSEVELT OUT FOR H. D. HINMAN; Perkins and Robinson Tell the Colonel Progressives Will Accept the Republican.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 22. -- Col. Theodore Roosevelt made public tonight a statement in which he advocated the nomination of ex-State Senator Harvey D. Hinman of Broome County, an independent Republican, for Governor by the Progressives.

headline: HENNESSY NON-COMMITTAL.; Says He Has Not Decided on Race for Governor.
leadPara: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 22. -John H. Hennessy, who fought for the Fusion cause in New York City last Fall, passed through here today on his way to Catskill to confer with leaders regarding the political situation in this part of the State. Mr. Hennessy admitted while here that independent Democrats wanted him to run for Governor but he said he would not make known his decision for several days.

Hinman of Binghamton stands well with the Republicans of this city, a majority of whom apparently believe that he would be a stronger candidate for Governor than Whitman. headline: St. Lawrence for Whitman.
leadPara: OGDENSBURG, July 23. -- Sentiment among the rank and file of voters in St. Lawrence County favors Whitman. Several Republican leaders who were interviewed said that they would support the District Attorney for Governor.

headline: Chautauqua Warms to Hinman.
leadPara: JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 23. -- The sentiment of Republicans and Progressives of Chautauqua County apparently largely favors the nomination of Harvey D. Hinman for Governor. This was a Progressive stronghold in the campaign of 1912, and from that day to this the Republican leaders have been making efforts to get the Progressives back into the fold. They believe that Hinman's nomination would help bring this about.

headline: QUACK ADVERTISEMENTS.; Public Can Help to Rid the Newspapers of Them.
leadPara: THE NEW YORK TIMES will do both the public and the better class of advertisers a great favor in whatever it may do to uphold Dr. Goldwater's hands in his war against drugs and patent medicines for which false representations are made. It seems too bad that so many newspaper publishers should delay the throwing out of misleading advertising.
abstract: letter on quack advertisements

headline: Tioga Leader Supports Hinman.
LAWYER SAYS HEINZE MISLED THE COURT; Affidavits Assert Man Alleged to be Seriously Ill Enjoyed Life at Long Beach.
abstract: will not run in Queens County elections

headline: IN CENTRAL COUNTIES; Onondaga Supports Hinman.
leadPara: SYRACUSE, July 23. -- Ray B. Smith, ex-Clerk of the Assembly and leader of the more progressive wing of the Republican organization, said today: "I am for Hinman, absolutely. I was associated with him in the Legislature for many years, personally and otherwise. I regard Senator Hinman as eminently qualified for the position of Governor. Of all the candidates mentioned so far, he is the best qualified."

headline: HINMAN FINDS FRIENDS UP-STATE; Times Canvass Shows That Many Leaders Hail Him as a Strong Candidate.
abstract: Up-State canvass for Harvey D. Hinman shows his strength

headline: ROOSEVELT'S PLAN FOR FUSION.
leadPara: Col. ROOSEVELT'S programme for the Fail campaign is before the people. In other States he will attack the Wilson Administration, but not here. Here he regards as the paramount need the election of a non-partisan State ticket, because in New York there is an "invisible government" headed by BARNES and MURPHY, and the people have never been able to escape from one except into the arms of the other.
abstract: editorial

headline: COLONEL IS "MAKING SLATE."; Will Consult Independents as Well as Bull Moose.
abstract: Roosevelt will consult Independents as well as Progressives for selection of rest of ticket

headline: MOOSE FUNDS RUN LOW.; Party Paying Only 50 Cents on the Dollar in Massachusetts.
abstract: party only paying 50 cents on the dollar

headline: Herkimer Sees Hinman Strength.
STIMSON TO HEAD PLATFORM DRAFTERS; Sub-Committee of Nine Will Submit Republican Views on Revision.
abstract: platform committee presided over by Root and headed by Stimson hold meeting, sub-committee of nine to submit views on revision of State Constitution, delegation of woman suffragists received and plea for suffrage plank made, Andrew D. White not a candidate for U. S. Sen.

headline: ROOSEVELT SEIZES LIBEL SUIT AS ISSUE; Spends Three Hours with Lawyer in Preparing Answer to Barnes.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 24. -- A three-hour conference was held this afternoon at Sagamore Hill by Col. Roosevelt and Willian H. Van Benschoten of the law firm of Bowers Sands of New York, at which Col. Roosevelt's answer to the complaint filed by William Barnes in his $50,000 libel suit which Barnes has started was discussed.
abstract: statement on Roosevelt's preparations for suit

headline: Article 12 -- No Title
Article 16 -- No Title
leadPara: HUDSON, July 24. -- Charles Tracy of Ghent, Chairman of the Republican County Committee of Columbia County, said today that for some time he had favored the nomination of Whitman and saw no reason to change his opinion. He believed he would make a strong candidate and an excellent Governor.
abstract: trial trip shows wireless and compass working well

headline: HEDGES MOCKS AT 'NOISY PROMISE'; Candidate for Governor in 1912 Is in the Race Against Whitman.
leadPara: Job E. Hedges, who was the Republican candidate for Governor in 1912 against William Sulzer, Democrat, and Oscar S. Straus, Progressive, made formal announcement yesterday that he intends to be a candidate at the primaries on Sept. 28 for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination again this year. Mr. Hedges said he would accept no other nomination.
abstract: Hedges announces his candidacy for Gov.

headline: $50,000 WON ON EMPIRE CITY RACE; Belle of Bryn Mawr Heavily Played at Track and in Poolrooms.
leadPara: There was not much class to the racing at the Empire City track yesterday, the card being made up of overnight events. The main purpose seemed to be to give the non-winners a chance to win enough to pay the oat bills. Strong favorites and outsiders in the speculation divided honors, Butwell riding the three favorites, Belle of Bryn Mawr, Punch Bowl, and Monocacy.
abstract: Belle of Bryn Mawr wins, summary, entries

headline: MOOSE LOSE IN KENTUCKY.; Court Denies New Party Representation on Election Boards.
abstract: Court denies party representation on election boards

headline: AMERICAN BUSINESS MEN BECOME WORLD LEADERS; International Congress of Chambers of Commerce at Paris Proves It -- They Suggested International Commercial Arbitration.
leadPara: THE fact that the American business man is rapidly achieving a place much higher than he has ever held before in the minds of the European commercial community has just been strikingly evidenced.

headline: WE FACE THE MOST ACUTE SPIRITUAL CRISIS OF HISTORY; So Thinks Dr. Rudolf Eucken, Philosopher and Nobel Prize Winner, Who Says That the Christian Religion Can Only Be Maintained If It Is Sweepingly Changed from Outside the Churches.
leadPara: CAN we still be Christians?" Rudolf Eucken asks the question in his latest book, the query being taken as the volume's title. And he answers that "we not only can but must be Christians -- only, however, on the condition that Christianity be recognized as a progressive historic movement still in the making, that it be shaken free from the numbing influence of ecclesiasticism and placed upon a broader foundation.

headline: INVENTORS HAVE BETTER CHANCE TO MAKE FORTUNES NOW THAN BEFORE; Millennium Has Not Dawned for Them by Any Means, but Present Conditions Afford Them More Protection Against Being Robbed.
leadPara: IS A NEW ERA at hand for inventors? Has the World so changed that the man who used to be "robbed" of his "great idea" now makes a fortune from it? Has the golden age of invention dawned?

headline: JOHNSON AND ROOSEVELT.; Governor Makes General Denial of Break with the Colonel.
leadPara: SAN FRANCISCO, July 25. -- Gov. Hiram W. Johnson made a general denial today of the report that he had broken with Col. Roosevelt. The Governor, however, would not discuss his conversation with Rufus Rockwell Nelson, originator of the Western Commercial Congress, in which he was said to have assailed the Colonel and refused to invite him to the Congress.
abstract: telegram denying break with Roosevelt

headline: ROOSEVELT READY FOR CAMPAIGN TRIPS; Is Working On an Important Speech Attacking Wilson in Boston Next Month.
leadPara: OYSTER, BAY, L.I., July 26. -- Satisfied that he has given the standpat Republicans and Democrats of New York State much to worry them by the manner in which he has complicated the situation, Col. Roosevelt bas begun to give some of his time to the problems which confront the Progressive Party in other States.
abstract: editorial

headline: HINMAN HAS MADE NO PLEDGES, HE SAYS; Will Be the Candidate of Any Party That Opposes Barnes and Murphy
leadPara: Harvey D. Hinman, who announced that he would seek the Republican Gubernatorial nomination at the September primaries and whose candidacy Col. Roosevelt enthusiastically indorsed, came to New York yesterday, and after going over the political situation with some of his advisers issued a statement last night, the first since the announcement of his candidacy.
abstract: issues statement, attacks Barnes and Murphy

headline: HENNESSY TO ROOSEVELT.; Told Colonel He Would Enter No Movement Not Strictly Non-Partisan
POLICE CLEAR DEADHEAD HILL OF PIKERS; Fifty-Cent Bookmakers Also Scattered from Point Outside Yonkers Track.
leadPara: " Getaway week" began at the Empire City track yesterday with the material breaking up of the popularity of the Deadhead Hill betting field by the presence of a few more Yonkers policemen, who scattered the nondescript gathering and curbed the operations of the fifty-cent bookmakers who had been operating there.
abstract: races

headline: WHITMAN TO ENTER ONLY ONE PRIMARY; Pledges Support to Republican Nominee and Challenges Hinman to Do So.
leadPara: District Attorney Charles S. Whitman issued a statement last night announcing that he would enter the Republican primary and none other. He said he would support the Republican candidate chosen at the primary and he called upon Harvey D. Hinman to state whether he would make a like pledge.
abstract: Whitman to enter only one primary

headline: WILSON TO GO ON STUMP.; Will Speak in Districts Where Democratic Congressmen Need Help.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Democratic Congressmen have succeeded in convincing Administration officials that there is great danger that the present Democratic majority in the House will be overturned at the November elections. That this feeling has had its influence on the President was indicated today when it became known that Mr. Wilson had determined to make speeches for Democratic Congressional candidates in the forthcoming campaign.
abstract: Pres. Wilson to go on stump in districts where Democratic Congressmen need help

headline: MAY NOT TRY TO BAN UNFAIR PRACTICES; Democrats Likely to Cut Section on Competition from Trade Commission Bill.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, July 28. -- So much opposition to the section prohibiting "unfair competition" has arisen within and without the party ranks that Democratic leaders are seriously considering the abandonment of Section 5 of the Trade Commission bill, which embodies it. In the meantime, realizing that bitter Republican criticism will be directed against the section, they are trying to use the provision for trading purposes.
abstract: criticises trade commission bill

headline: DID WHITMAN VOTE FOR TAFT?; Told the Colonel and Others He Voted for Roosevelt in 1912.
abstract: thinks Whitman statement weak and misleading, wants to know if Whitman voted for Taft in 1912, pleased over statement of Hinman, to speak in his interests

headline: MR. WHITMAN'S PLATFORM.
leadPara: Mr. WHITMAN is not impressive when he is declaring defiantly, "Nei"ther can Mr. BARNES prevent me "from getting the nomination," and at the same time using the Barnes organization up-State to get his petitions out and holding conferences with Mr. BARNES at his home.
abstract: Mr. Whitman's platform, editorial

headline: BARNES DENIES ALL HINMAN'S CHARGES; "Absolutely False," He Says -- "Never Dickered or Dealt with Murphy." N.Y. COUNTY WORRIES HIM Koenig, Mills, and Parsons Said to be Considering Indorsement of Roosevelt Candidate.
leadPara: Chairman William Barnes of the Republican State Committee put Harvey D. Hinman, candidate for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, in the Ananias Club yesterday. Mr. Barnes said:
abstract: Barnes denies his charges, Koenig, Mills, and Parsons said to be considering his indorsement, John B. Rose to manage his campaign, overtures made to Kings County Leader Jacob Livingston

headline: THINK ROOSEVELT PLANS 1916 FUSION; Ormsby McHarg Tells Him the Two Parties Must Come Together. PROUTY TO BE INDORSED Politicians Say Colonel's Plans All Appear to be to Unite Republicans and Progressives.
leadPara: Many politicians decided yesterday that Col. Theodore Roosevelt is shaping his course with the idea in view of bringing about a union of the Republican and Progressive Parties for the Presidential campaign of 1916. Many things happened which pointed to that conclusion in the three hours which Col. Roosevelt spent at National Progressive Headquarters in the Forty-second Street Building.
abstract: leaders think he plans fusion for 1916

headline: WHITMAN'S 'A TIMID SOUL,' SAYS DUELL; "A Spring Lie or a Summer Lie," Comments Organizer of Non-Partisan League. "ROOSEVELT HIS IDOL" Colonel Gives Out Long Telegram Which Reveals a Broken Political Friendship.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 29. -- Upon his return to Oyster Bay tonight Col. Roosevelt gave out a long telegram received from Charles H. Duell, Jr., in which Mr. Duell made another attack upon District Attorney Charles S. Whitman. The telegram was sent by Mr. Duell from Springfield, Mass.
abstract: attacks on Hinman continue in his newspaper

headline: CORDIER AND DANA VICTORS ON COURT; Appel and Onatavia, Too, Win Matches in National Handicap Squash Tourney.
leadPara: Among several defaults yesterday in the national handicap squash tennis tournament at the Harvard Club was that of Fillmore S. Hyde, rated as one of the strongest contestants in the event and by many considered as most likely to finish in first place. Hyde was obliged to default his third-round match against H. W. Warner of the Columbia Club because of illness.

headline: Austria Hurls 500,000 Men in Four Divisions at Servia.; DANUBE AND SAVE CROSSED March Southward on the Road to Nish Begun, Following Capture of Belgrade. BIG BATTLE IN BOSNIA Servians Reported to Have Been Defeated There, with Loss of 800 Men. MONTENEGRINS IN CATTARO Occupy Dalmatian Seaport Covered by Their Guns on Mount Lovtchen -- Greece Ready to Mobilize.
