headline: ROOSEVELT FAVORS 'FUSION IN SPOTS'; Republicans Must Dethrone Their Bosses, He Tells Maine Delegation PLAYS POLITICS FOR 1916 Says Progressives Are Willing to Work Hand in Hand With Rank and File of Old Party.
abstract: denounced by Roosevelt

headline: McREYNOLDS IN THE LEAD.; Likely to be Named to Supreme Bench ;- Gregory as Successor.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, July 31. -- A member of the Cabinet, through a Democratic Senator, has made an informal canvass of the Senate to find out what opposition there would be to the appointment of Attorney General McReynolds to the Supreme bench. The Senator's report was favorable, and the belief is general that Mr. McReynolds will be appointed, though it is known that the post has not been offered to him yet.
abstract: may be appointed Atty. Gen. if McReynolds is named for Supreme Court

headline: ROOSEVELT REUNION GETS MORE SUPPORT; Maryland Progressive Leader Tells Colonel That State Is Ready for Fusion. MAY PUT UP BONAPARTE Elimination of Certain Bosses Who Balked T.R. in 1912 the Paramount Condition.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, Aug. 1. -- Col. Roosevelt heard today that Maryland Progressive leaders were for a reunion of the Progressive and Republican Parties if certain bosses are eliminated before the campaign of 1916.
abstract: may be fusion candidate for U. S. Sen. from Maryland

headline: DR. CHARLES R. VAN HISE DISSECTS THE ANTI-TRUST BILLS; Suggests the Addition of a Clause by Which Corporations May Ask the Advice of' the Interstate Commission as to Whether Proposed or Existing Practices Are Legal.
leadPara: RECENTLY public sentiment has developed rapidly in regard to the manner of control of big business. Three years ago when the control of corporations through trade commissions was proposed, the idea was favored by few; but it has now gained much ground.

headline: MAN NEEDS WORSHIP AS HE DOES FOOD AND SLEEP; Dr. Richard C. Cabot of Harvard Sets Forth in a Book the Therapeutic Value of Prayer ;- He Prescribes Work, Play, Love, and Worship as Necessary for "Every Human Being."
leadPara: WORSHIP is needed by men and women "regularly like food or sleep." It relieves "spiritual fatigue," for souls get drained of energy as do bodies, and when the spirit is tired there is "loss of power," in addition to "a lack of feeling for life."

headline: INLAND FROM NAVESINK HIGHLANDS TO QUAINT OLD CHAPEL HILL
leadPara: LONG before Summer resorters disported themselves in tango-colored bathing suits, before pagoda-shaped parasols parade along boardwalks, before husbands pined in Manhattan's August solitude, the same dignified old Highlands rose above the gleaming white sand of the Jersey shore, the same lean old peninsula of Sandy Hook crooked its finger out into the same old Atlantic Ocean, and the Navesink River opened its wide mouth as now, near the "Horseshoe" of Sandy Hook Bay.

headline: SENATE FOR DRASTIC TRADE REGULATION; It Grants New Commission the Right to Consider Competition and Call It Illegal. REVIEW POWER TO COURTS Non-Partisan Vote Carries Mr. Cummins's Amendment ;- Text of His Proposal.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Democratic Senators of the Committee on Interstate Commerce were taken completely by surprise today when, by a vote of 33 to 25, the Senate adopted the more drastic substitute proposed by Mr. Cummins of Iowa, a Progressive Republican, for Section 5 of the Trade Commission bill.
abstract: Senate adopts Cummins's drastic amendment concerning unfair competition

headline: POLITICS AND PRINCIPLE IN LEGISLATION.
leadPara: The legislative situation of the trust bills at Washington is at a point which lends exceptional interest to the article in THE TIMES SUNDAY MAGAZINE by President VAN HISE of the University of Wisconsin. He is a Progressive of the Progressives, but he is not a politician.
abstract: editorial on Dr. Van Hise's special article

headline: NOTED AMERICANS STRANDED ABROAD; H. W. Taft, M. L. Schiff, Judge Gary, and Cardinal Farley Among Those Marooned. MAY HAMPER THE SCHOOLS So Many Teachers Are Trapped In Europe That Openings May Be Delayed.
leadPara: Among the Americans stranded in Paris are three New York State Senators -- John Murtaugh, James A. Foley, and James F. Frawley, with Mrs. Frawley -- who have been in Europe on a special commission in the interests of the San Francisco Exposition. They are at the Hotel Astra.

headline: HOW WILL WOMEN VOTE?; Big Issue in Kansas Primary Today ;- Missouri Voting Also.
leadPara: TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 3. -- With 300,000 feminine voters registered, political forecasters have little to say regarding tomorrow's State-wide primary. All parties but the Republican have made a bid for the new vote by nominating at least one woman for a State or Congressional office.
abstract: women voters big issues in primaries

headline: GRANTS BILLION CURRENCY ISSUE; Congress Agrees to Amend Aldrich-Vreeland Act to Give Banks More Latitude. TO PASS MEASURE TODAY Under It Banks May Issue Currency to 125 Per Cent. of Capital and Surplus. PARTY LINES ARE DROPPED Republicans and Democrats Call for Unanimous Support of Measure to Meet Unprecedented Emergency.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- With amendments from both the House and Senate, a conference committee this evening arrived at an agreement on the final form of Senator Owen's bill changing the Aldrich-Vreeland act so as to liberalize its provisions and make it more available for use in the present emergency.
abstract: statement favoring amendment to Aldrich-Vreeland act

headline: BIRD IS FOR HINMAN, BUT SULZER VEXES; Bull Moose in Conference Today May Hear the Deposed Governor. COL. ROOSEVELT TO TALK Suffragists Insist on Reaffirmation of Woman Plank Because Hinman Is Still an Anti.
leadPara: Whether or not the Progressives are to support Harvey D. Hinman as their candidate for Governor at the primaries next month will be determined today when the Progressive State Committee will hold a conference at the Hotel Astor. Indications are that Col. Roosevelt has succeeded in "putting over" Mr. Hinman and that there will be little opposition to him.
abstract: delegation headed by Mrs. Blatch presents protest against Hinman at Progressive headquarters, ask for reaffirmation of woman plank in Progressive platform

headline: TRADE BOARD BILL PASSES THE SENATE; First of Three Anti-Trust Measures of the President Is Adopted by 53 Votes to 16. MAJORITY IS BIPARTISAN Four of Regular Republicans Support It ;- Stock and Bond Bill Comes Up Next.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- President Wilson won what was perhaps his greatest legislative triumph this afternoon when the Senate, by the overwhelming bipartisan vote of 53 to 16, passed the Trade Commission bill.
abstract: amendment adopted

headline: SENATOR BRISTOW'S MISHAP.
leadPara: The nominations of Mr. WARBURG and Mr. DELANO to fill the two vacancies upon the Federal Reserve directorate were reported favorably upon the same day that the Kansas primaries are reported to have gone against Senator BRISTOW. If his opponent, CHARLES CURTIS of Topeka, shall carry the State by 15,000, as he expects upon the returns, the opposition to Mr. WARBURG will have met a Just rebuke where most creditable and least to be expected.
abstract: Sen. Bristow's mishap, editorial

leadPara: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5. -- Senator Wm. J. Stone has been renominated on the Democratic ticket by 10,000 plurality T. J. Atkins of St. Louis seems to have beaten P. Elvins for the Republican nomination. Arthur N. Sager had no opposition on the Progressive ballot.

headline: MUTINY AMONG THE MOOSE.
leadPara: It is a mistake to suppose that Col. ROOSEVELT has only one fight on his hands. He has two. He is not going to take the Progressives with him on his fusion road without trouble. The leaders will go, with however little heart, for they can see the political necessity of it; but the rank and file are not so tractable.
abstract: editorial

headline: COL. ROOSEVELT MAY STUMP FOR HINMAN; Prepared to Fight Entire Party, if Necessary, to Carry His Point. HEARS PROTESTS GROWING Has State Committee's Support and Thinks Colby and Others Can Be Brought Into Line.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 6. -- Protests which have been made to Col. Roosevelt by prominent Progressives since the State Committee meeting on Wednesday against the Indorsement of Harvey J. Hinman for Governor are receiving scant consideration. So far as the Colonel is concerned the matter is settled for all time.

headline: U.S. ARMY TRAINING BEST IN THE WORD; Other Armies Drilled In Fixed Divisions, While U.S. Officers Take New Posts at Short Notice. ALLOWS FOR GROWTH Report Prepared for Commissioner of Education with Approval of Gen. Wood Describes Army Education.
leadPara: The United States has a more thorough and far-going system of professional scholastic training for the officers in the army than any other nation, according to a special report prepared by Capt. Douglas MacArthur for United States Commissioner of Education Claxton, and approved by Gen. Leonard Wood.
abstract: Educational Systems in the American Army

headline: ROAMER SETS NEW MARKS IN TRAVERS; Andrew Miller's Colt Wins Old Saratoga Stakes and Makes Two Records.
leadPara: SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Roamer, Andrew Miller's little son of Knight Errant and Rose Tree, and winner of the Brooklyn Derby and the Carter Handicap, added the historic Travers Stakes to his list at the course of the Saratoga Association this afternoon. His victory was the most impressive in the fifty years that the old fixture has been one of the most important on the American turf.

headline: ROOSEVELT AVERTS SPLIT OVER HINMAN; Bull Moose Leaders in Line for the Republican, but They Are Grumbling. WON'T STAND FOR CALDER Colonel Will Face a Revolt if He Tries to Carry Conciliation Policy Any Further.
leadPara: The threatened revolt among Progressive leaders against giving Harvey D. Hinman, the anti-Barnes Republican candidate for the Gubernatorial nomination, the Bull Moose indorsement in the primaries will not materialize. But there is no end of soreness among Progressive leaders at the Colonel's policy in committing the Progressive Party in this State to Hinman's candidacy in advance of any consultation on the subject.
abstract: Roosevelt averts split over Hinman, opposition to Calder, Queens County Committee designates Hinman

headline: GERMAN GENERAL FORETOLD GERMAN'S WAR PLANS; GERMAN GENERAL FORETOLD GERMANY'S WAR PLANS
leadPara: OVER two years ago Gen. Friedrich von Bernhardi, of the German Army, considered one of the leading authorities on military matters in Europe, wrote a book called "Germany and the Next War," in which he outlined with startling exactness the very course which Germany is now pursuing in her war against her foes.

headline: OHIO STATE PRIMARY TODAY; All Parties to Nominate Tickets ;- Light Vote Is Expected.
leadPara: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 10. -- A Statewide primary, preceded by marked apathy until within the last few days, will be held in this State tomorrow for the nomination of candidates for all State offices except Auditor, candidates for United States Senator, Congressmen in twenty-two districts, members of the Legislature, and county tickets in all of the eighty-eight counties.

headline: BUYERS FLOCK HERE FOR CLAFLIN SALE; Threatened Shortage of Foreign Goods Brings Many Purchasers in Search of Bargains. MOST PRICES REDUCED Demand for Foreign Knit Goods and French and German Dress Goods Particularly Heavy.
leadPara: Buyers from all parts of the country availed themselves yesterday of the opportunity of getting Fall and Winter merchandise at reduced prices, afforded by the special sale held at the rooms of the H. B. Claflin Company in this city. The sale was under the direction of Joseph B. Martindale and Frederic A. Juilliard, receivers for the Claflin concern, and prices were cut on all articles with the exception of flannels and blankets.

leadPara: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 10. -- After two days of mourning, the late President, Dr. Roque Saenz Pena, will be buried tomorrow.

leadPara: SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Racing at the course of the Saratoga Association this afternoon was principally interesting and important for the reason that Senator Johnson N. Camden's twoyear-old, Solly, hung out a new track record for the five and a half furlong distance.

headline: HIS OWN DISTRICT TURNS DOWN SULZER; Sixth Assembly Bull Moose Indorse Bainbridge Colby for Governor. PARSONS IS FOR WHITMAN Hinman to Get a Good Vote In New York County, It Is Believed ;- Chase for Appeals Bench.
leadPara: Dr. Arthur Kozma, Progressive leader of the Sixth Assembly District, informed Bainbridge Colby yesterday that his district organization had indorsed him as a candidate for Governor. In the Fifth District, where P. T. Cavegan is the Bull Moose leader, the organization, after defeating resolutions to indorse Mr. Hinman, adopted a resolution in Mr. Colby's favor on Monday night.

headline: MR. HINMAN DENIES ANY ROOSEVELT DEAL; Colonel's Support Voluntary and Carries No Obligation, Express or Implied. WON'T USE OFFICE FOR '16 Seeks Governorship as Loyal Republican, Candidate Tells Convention ;- Denounces Present Party Control.
leadPara: PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- Denial that there had been any "trade, dicker or deal" between himself and Col. Roosevelt, or that he would use public office to further Mr. Roosevelt's nomination for President in 1916, was made in an address which Harvey D. Hinman of Binghamton, candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, delivered before the Republican County Convention in Plattsburg late this afternoon.
abstract: denies that he is candidate for Controller

headline: FUSION IN PENNSYLVANIA.; Dean Lewis Invited to Get Off the Bull Moose Ticket.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, Aug. 12. -- William Draper Lewis, who was chosen at the Bull Moose primaries in Pennsylvania as the Progressive candidate for Governor, came here today and had a two hours' talk with Col. Roosevelt. Medill McCormick, who was also here, took him back to New York on his yacht.
abstract: petitions started for nomination of Lindon W. Bates, Jr., for N. Y. Sen. from Seventeenth District

headline: SOLID BARNES DELEGATION.; Chairman Will Head Albany Contingent at State Convention.
abstract: Lucoen Knapp is seeking nomination for Congress in Second District

headline: Nassau Bull Moose for Hinman.
abstract: W. W. Cocks indorsed as Congressional candidate, Leroy J. Weed for Assemblyman in Nassau County

headline: ROOSEVELT OFF TOMORROW.; Speaks In Hartford at Night and Goes to Boston and Maine.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Col. Roosevelt will start from Sagamore Hill early on Saturday morning on a four-days' tour of New England. He will motor with his son Archie to Farmington, Conn., arriving there at 5 o'clock, and will have dinner with his sister, Mrs. Cowles, wife of Rear Admiral Cowles. He will then motor to Hartford, Conn., and deliver an address to the Progressives.

headline: ROOSEVELT GOES TO HARTFORD; To Speak There Tonight ;- Thinks Hennessy Will Aid Hinman.
abstract: to speak in Hartford, thinks Hennessy will aid Hinman

headline: DOUBLE WIN FOR WHITNEY STABLES; Gainer and Spun Glass Get Home First at Saratoga Races.
leadPara: SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Gainer, the three-year-old for which Mrs. Payne Whitney paid $12,500 at the sale of the J.L. Holland horses at Belmont Park in the Spring, was winner of the best race offered by the Saratoga Association this afternoon. The race was hardly befitting such a colt, for he only beat ordinary handicap horses.
abstract: Gainer and Spun Glass win

headline: Article 23 -- No Title
leadPara: THERE was a time when a man could wear his last year's suit without feeling conscious of the fact, but that was some time ago. In the large cities and progressive towns of this country the element of style in men's wear is playing an increasingly important part.

headline: ROOSEVELT A BAR IN HINMAN'S RACE; Resentment at Colonel's Support Among the Republicans Gathering for Convention. ALL COMING BARNES'S WAY Finds Erstwhile Foes Uniting with Him for Whitman ;- Old Faces Seen at Saratoga.
leadPara: SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- That Col. Roosevelt's support had come more or less as a blight to Harvey D. Hinman, who expects to enter the Republican and Progressive primaries as a candidate for the Gubernatorial nomination, was the comment heard tonight among the Republican leaders assembling here for the unofficial convention next Tuesday.
abstract: Republicans gathering for convention resent Roosevelt support

headline: WANTS DATA ON INCOMES.; Murdock Aiming at Inheritance Tax as Federal Revenue Producer.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Victor Murdock, the Progressive leader in the House, who declares that certain Americans, fewer than 2,000 in number, have incomes which are greater than the total income of the Government, offered a resolution today asking the Treasury Department for information as to big incomes with a view to certain legislation, Mr. Murdock seeks data upon which to base a Federal inheritance tax law.
abstract: introduces resolution asking Treasury Dept. for data on incomes with view to framing inheritance tax law

headline: Westchester Moose for Hinman.
leadPara: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 15. -- The Progressive County Committee of Westchester, at a specially called meeting here last night, adopted resolutions indorsing Harvey D. Hinman for Governor. There was one dissenting vote. Robert Mongrief, of this village, wanted the indorsement for William Sulzer, but he only raised a laugh.
abstract: S. B. Ayres for Congress from Twenty-third Dist.

headline: THE GERMAN VIEWPOINT; Should Be Considered by Americans in Judging Present War.
leadPara: May I plead for a little fair play in the consideration of Germany's status in the present conflict? Americans have always had the reputation of being "good sports." To my mind an essential of good sportsmanship is to get the other man's point of view.

headline: COLONEL TELLS WHY HE IS FOR HINMAN; It's to Beat Bosses of Both Old Parties ;- Connecticut Moose Wanted to Know. DISCUSSES WAR IN SPEECH But for Monroe Doctrine We Might Be Embroiled, He Declares ;- Sees Danger in Bryan Peace Treaties.
leadPara: HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 15. -- Theodore Roosevelt opened his New England campaign at the Parsons Theatre tonight with a long address, much of which was devoted to an explanation to the Connecticut Progressives of his reason for indorsing Harvey D. Hinman, a Republican, for the Governorship of New York.
abstract: Roosevelt calls it antiquated in speech before Conn. Progressives

headline: GIFFORD PINCHOT WEDS MISS BRYCE; Progressive Senatorial Nominee Marries Daughter of Gen. and Mrs. Lloyd S. Bryce. QUIET NUPTIALS AT ROSLYN Col. and Mrs. Roosevelt, ex-Ambassador Bacon, and Mr. and Mrs. J.R. Garfield Among Guests.
abstract: marriage

headline: BAYLIS ATTACKS WHITMAN.; Says District Attorney Read Duell's Anti-Boss Draft to Him.
leadPara: Dr. Charles T. Baylis, a prominent Progressive, made public yesterday an auti-Whitman letter which he has sent to ex-State Senator Frederick C. Stevens at the Republican Convention in Saratoga Dr. Baylis attacked District Attorney Whitman and corroborated Charles H. Duell, Jr., in saying that Mr. Whitman had seen and approved the rough draft of the letter with which Mr. Duell tried to win Col. Roosevelt's favor for the District Attorney.
abstract: Fisher, Patrick, shot in church by Joseph Burton, injury slight

headline: ROOSEVELT OFF TO VERMONT; Calls Visit to His Fellow-Explorer Cherrie His "Day Off."
leadPara: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Aug. 16. -Theodore Roosevelt made an automobile trip of nearly 120 miles today through Connecticut, Massachusetts, and Vermont, to visit his fellowexplorer and Progressive, George K. Cherrie, at Newfant, twelve miles from here.
abstract: visits George K. Cherrie

headline: NO ALLIANCE, SAYS GOV. GLYNN; Hasn't Made Common Cause with Hearst in Primary Campaign.
leadPara: ALBANY, Aug. 17. -- Gov. Glynn's friends are angry over the imputations that the Governor has Sartered for support of his candidacy for the Gubernatorial nomination. They say that his support of the Wilson Administration cannot be questioned. They say, however, that if the Wilson men pick fight with Gov. Glynn he will fight back and that it will be some fight.
abstract: Tammany to back his candidacy, Stetson wants him nominated, says he has made no alliance with Hearst

headline: TAMMANY TO BACK GLYNN'S CANDIDACY; Murphy May Select McCombs, Osborn, or Gerard for United States Senator.
leadPara: Tammany Hall is to stand behind Gov. Glynn in his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor, it was announced yesterday. It will begin active work at once to have its full strength brought out at the primaries for the Governor. Francis Lynde Stetson gave out a statement favoring the Governor yesterday, and it was said that he has the support of National Chairman McCombs and State Chairman Osborn.
abstract: Tammany to back Glynn's candidacy, Glynn says he hasn't made common cause with Hearst

headline: A HINT TO THE REPUBLICANS.
leadPara: It is true that one Progressive nostrum may be more reactionary and worse than another, and we have no mind to dispute Senator ROOT'S dictum that the recall of the judiciary is the worst of the brood hatched in Pandora's box ready for loosing. Yet there are others whose practical working makes it worth while to stop their progress.
abstract: Bank depositors' guarantee act petitions voted illegal, editorial

headline: MRS. PINCHOT IN CAMPAIGN.; Will Spend Honeymoon in Working for Her Husband's Election.
abstract: will spend honeymoon in working for her husband's election

headline: HINMAN WON'T RUN AS A BULL MOOSE; Not to As Support for Any Nominee of Other Than Republican Party.
leadPara: SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- If Harvey D. Hinman fails to win the Republican nomination for Governor and is nominated by the Progressives he will remain in the Republican Party and refuse to make a campaign on the Progressive ticket. This is in substance the position taken by Mr. Hinman in a statement tonight.
abstract: Whitman slate is made up

headline: ROOSEVELT MEETS DAMPER AT BOSTON; Small Crowd at Fenway Park and Only 2,500 People in Big Arena.
leadPara: BOSTON, Aug. 17. -- From the Progressive viewpoint, Col. Roosevelt's invasion of Massachusetts today was anything but a huge success. Bad management, stormy weather, and the fact that there is very little active interest in politics here as yet, all combined to keep the crowds away.
abstract: report that he collapses

headline: CHEERS ONLY FOR ROOT.; Convention Session Was Dull and Listless Otherwise.
leadPara: SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Aside from a magnificent ovation for United States Senator Elihu Root, when he took the gavel as temporary Chairman, the opening session of the convention was as dull and listless as 600 docile, hand-picked delegates could make it. A programme, arranged many days in advance, went through with all the well-oiled smoothness of the good old days when the Platt and Odell machines were in their glory.
abstract: convention opens, Root delivers keynote speech, Whitman makes good impression on leaders, W. D. Guthrie made Chairman of Committee on Resolutions, woman suffrage resolution referred to committee, delegates at large for Constitutional Convention picked, recall of judiciary denounced

headline: ATTACKS THE ADMINISTRATION; Senator Root Says Progressive Party Has Disappeared.
leadPara: SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Senator Root charged that the Democratic Party had failed. He took up particularly the tariff legislation which he asserted had been carried out in a spirit of hostility to American industry, and suggested that "perhaps the time has now come when the American people are ready again to try the protective system upon its merits and to call for legislation inspired by a spirit of friendliness toward American industry."
abstract: attacks Democratic and Progressive parties

headline: ROOSEVELT GREETED BY CROWDS IN MAINE; Makes Two Speeches and Hammers Wilson's Panama Canal Policy. AVOIDS ALL FUSION TALK Weary of "Misgovernment by Lawsuit," He Says of New Haven Dissolution Action.
leadPara: PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 18. -- The Progressives of Maine gave Col. Roosevelt a rousing welcome today, and he responded with two stirring speeches in which he bitterly assailed the Democratic Administration and the bosses and stood firmly by the policies on which the new party founded.
abstract: E. P. Costigun, gubernatorial candidate, receives letter from Roosevelt

headline: M'REYNOLDS CHOSEN FOR SUPREME COURT; President Wilson Will Send His Appointment to the Senate Today.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The first change in President Wilson's Cabinet will be announced tomorrow, when the President will send to the Senate the name of Attorney General James Clark McReynolds to be Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, to succeed the late Justice Horace Harmon Lurton.
abstract: chosen for Atty. Gen.; his career

headline: T. R. WRITES ON COLORADO.; Blames Both Big Political Parties and Rockefeller for State's Troubles.
leadPara: DENVER, Col., Aug. 18. -- Charging the State Government of Colorado for twenty-five years with having plunged the Commonwealth into bankruptcy, blaming John D. Rockefeller and the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company as instigators of the civil war that has reigned here in the coal fields, Col. Roosevelt in a letter published here tonight analyzes the Colorado labor situation as the most striking example in the country of corporation domination in Governmental affairs.
abstract: blamed by Roosevelt for plunging Commonwealth into bankruptcy

headline: "REUNION" UP TO DATE.
leadPara: The Republican Convention -- we refuse to use the absurd word "unofficial," since it is as official as any convention ever held -- has already had one positive political result. It has cleared the situation with regard to the talk of a reunion between the Republicans and Progressives which has been vaguely going on for months.
abstract: "Reunion" up to date, editorial

headline: LADY BARBARY WINS ADIRONDACK STAKE; Carman Entry Has to Run Good Race to Beat Trial by Jury.
leadPara: SARATOGA, Aug. 19. -- Richard F. Carman's Lady Barbary, winner of the Spinaway Stake, was the heroine of the stake feature at the course of the Saratoga Association this afternoon when she scored in the running of the Adirondack Handicap, a six furlong affair.
abstract: Adirondack Stakes, by Lady Barbary

headline: BARNES DEFEATED ON ONLY ROLL CALL; State Chairman Wants Ivins and Guthrie as Delegates at Large.
leadPara: SARATOGA, Aug. 19. -- By unanimous vote, the unofficial Republican State Convention today ratified the plan of the Republican National Committee for a sweeping reduction of the representation from the Democratic South in the National Conventions of the party. It adopted a platform which will make it exceedingly difficult for consistent candidates to run for office under joint Republican and Progressive auspices.
abstract: defeated on only roll call in convention

headline: "BLACK POPE" ALSO DEAD.; General of the Jesuits Dies Almost at the Same Hour as Pius X.
leadPara: ROME, Aug. 20. -- Father Francis Xavier Wernz, General of the Society of Jesus, known as "The Black Pope," died early this morning from diabetes, almost at the same hour as Pope Pius. His fatal illness was superinduced by his anxiety over the war. He had constantly prayed that victory should rest on the Austro-German arms, but was equally anxious in regard to the Jesuits in France.
abstract: death and career

headline: PROGRESSIVE LEADER DIES.; Ziba T. Moore of Philadelphia a Victim of Heart Disease.
BARNES TO FIGHT HINMAN.; State Chairman Says Roosevelt Is the Issue This Year.
leadPara: SARATOGA, Aug. 20. -- If William Barnes, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, has his way, the Republican primary contest about to begin will be fought with Roosevelt frankly as the issue. Mr. Barnes made it known that from now on he would use all his influence to bring about the defeat of Harvey D. Hinman in the primaries.
abstract: Holy Ghost or Dove orchid in bloom

headline: BULL MOOSE REVOLT AGAINST HINMAN; District Leaders Believe Roosevelt Can Yet Be Induced to Run. A FEW FAVOR HENNESSY Candidate's Statement at Saratoga Taken to Mean He Won't Campaign on Third Party Ticket.
leadPara: The revolt of the Progressive leaders in the city against Col. Roosevelt's candidate for Governor, Harvey D. Hinman, set in with a rush yesterday and it is very probable that within the next few days a delegation of determined Bull Moose will call upon the Colonel and urge him to consent to be the Party's candidate.
abstract: favored by a few Progressives

headline: ROOSEVELT RECALLS SUPPORT OF HINMAN; Colonel Now Favors a Straight-Out Third Party Ticket, for Which He Will Stump. WILL NOT RUN HIMSELF Hotchkiss or Davenport Favored for the Nomination ;- No Sentiment for Hinman.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 21. -- Col. Theodore Roosevelt tonight withdrew his recent indorsement of Harvey D. Hinman, a Republican, for the nomination as Governor on the Progressive ticket, and pledged himself in the most vigorous terms to the support of a straight-out third party fight in New York State.
abstract: favored for Progressive nominee for Gov. of N. Y.

headline: EUROPEAN WAR OPENS SOUTH AMERICA'S BIG MARKET TO US; Leading Financiers Are Already Arranging for Closer Economic Relations to Make Trading Easier with the Republics to the South of Us ;- City Bank's Important Plan.
leadPara: TREMENDOUS benefits to American trade and an incalculable increase in the prosperity of the business men of the United States are indicated to the minds of many careful students of economics by the simultaneous occurrence of two vast events, each epoch-making.

headline: COLONEL PLANS FOR FIGHT OF HIS CAREER; Realizes That He Has Burnt All His Bridges by Coming Out for a Straight Moose Ticket. MAY GO TO UTICA MEETING Roosevelt Says He Will Certainly Visit Every City in the State in the Campaign.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Realizing that he has burnt all of his bridges behind him by coming out in unqualified terms for a straight Progressive ticket in New York this Fall, Col. Theodore Roosevelt is planning one of the most vigorous campaigns of his career in an effort to overthrow the men he calls the bosses.
abstract: C. J. Hamlin announces candidacy for Gov.

headline: UPHOLDS DUELL'S STORY.; Baylis Says Whitman Showed Him Letter Denouncing Barnes.
leadPara: SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The Whitman-Roosevelt-Duell controversy is revived in what purports to be a letter from Dr. Charles T. Baylis of 2,501 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, to ex-Senator Frederick C. Stevens of Attica, N.Y., which was printed in The Saratogan this evening.
abstract: Dr. Baylis upholds Duell's story

headline: THE EUROPEAN STAGE AND THE WAR THERE.
leadPara: WHEN Edward V. Darling, chief booking expert of the Keith vaudeville circuit, was pleading with Ethel Barrymore at Long Beach last week not to give up the two-a-day for the legitimate, and finally prevailed upon her to appear this week at the Palace Theatre they fell to talking of the effect of the war upon the European stage.

headline: SEEK TO STAMPEDE MOOSE FOR COLONEL; State Committee Meeting at Utica Will Be Thrown Open to All Progressives. CALLS PRIMARY LAW A FARCE And Childs Says Elimination of Hinman Shows the Impossibility of Reforming the Republican Party.
leadPara: When the Progressive State Committee meets at Utica on Aug. 27 to discuss party candidates and policies it is planned to make it an old-fashioned mass meeting at which all those present may express their views fully. The leaders of the party believe that by such a meeting it may be possible to induce Col. Roosevelt to change his mind and to become the Bull Moose candidate for Governor.
abstract: C. J. Hamlin a candidate

abstract: editorial

headline: SENATE FAVORS WIDE WAREHOUSE LICENSE; Puts Storage of Cotton, Grain, and Tobacco Under Federal Supervision. BANKERS HOLD CONFERENCE Seek Solution of Cotton Problem ;- Menace of Surplus Crop Puzzles ;- McAdoo Warns State Banks.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The Senate this afternoon passed without a roll call the bill providing for Federal licenses for cotton warehouses after several amendments had been added extending the application of the measure to the local products of various parts of the country.
abstract: Senate passes bill; amendments extend its application to local products of various parts of country

headline: ROGER SULLIVAN'S CHANCES; Copley Thinks Vote for U.S. Senator Will Be Close.

headline: TOPICS OF THE TIMES.
leadPara: The Franco-German war was declared by NAPOLEON III, on July 14, 1870; the treaty of peace was signed at Frankfort on May 10, 1871. The Russo-Japanese war began with the breaking off of diplomatic negotiations on Feb. 5, 1904, and the Treaty of Portsmouth was signed on Aug. 23, 1905.

headline: ROOSEVELT WANTS FIGHT.; Tells Missouri Progressives That Republicans Have Not Reformed.

headline: I'M THE MAN,' SULZER TELLS ROOSEVELT; "Dead Sure" to Carry the Bull Moose Primaries for Governor. "HINMAN CLINCHED IT" Deposed Governor's Talk Lasted Three Hours ;- Colonel Says It Was "Most Interesting."
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 23. -- William Sulzer came to Oyster Bay today and told Col. Roosevelt flatly that he was positive he (Sulzer) would be nominated for Governor by the rank and file of the Progressive Party at the primaries. Sulzer was aggressive and positive in his assertions.
abstract: editorial

headline: DEMOCRATS EXPECT NO SLATEMAKING; State Conference Is Likely to Devote Itself to the Platform. MURPHY IS CARE-FREE Says Tammany is Standing by the Primary Law in Letter and in Spirit ;- No New Booms.
leadPara: SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- Charles F. Murphy, the Tammany leader, arrived this afternoon to take part in the Democratic State Conference tomorrow.

headline: OHIO FOR WILSON.; Indorse Administration in Platform ;- Progressives for Suffrage.
leadPara: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 25. -- Democrats and Progressives of Ohio adopted platforms at conventions held here today. The Republicans continued their platform convention throughout the day and adjourned until tomorrow, when final action is expected.
abstract: national prohibition and State equal suffrage amendment indorsed in platform adopted at convention, Roosevelt cheered

headline: NO SULZER BOOM AT UTICA.; Davenport, Hotchkiss, and Hamlin on the Ground.
leadPara: UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Two hundred Progressives from various parts of the State are in Utica tonight, preparing for the State Committee meeting tomorrow. Fifty came in two special cars from New York City. Among them were William H. Hotchkiss, Bainbridge Colby, and William H. Childs, Chairman of the Committee of Twenty-one.
abstract: Ardolph L. Kline announces his candidacy for Gov.

headline: PRINCE KROPOTKIN'S HOPES.
leadPara: It is significant that the veteran Russian agitator and democrat. Prince KROPOTKIN, supports the Government in this war on the express ground that, whatever the issue, "the " Russian military autocracy will not " gain, but all progressive and liberalizing " forces will be immensely " strengthened."
abstract: Prince Kropotkin's hopes

headline: ROOSEVELT'S FOOT ON SULZER'S BOOM; Colonel Says He's Neutral, but Leaders Take Cue From Him and Declare War. TALK NOW OF DAVENPORT Will Get Behind Him if No Better Appears and Proceed to Crush the "Sulzer Peril."
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 26. -- A bitter fight will be made by the State Committee of the Progressive Party to prevent William Sulzer from obtaining the Progressive nomination for Governor at the primaries. Col. Roosevelt remained neutral today when the name of Sulzer was mentioned, but there was plenty of evidence of opposition to the deposed Governor from other quarters.
abstract: says he is neutral in regard to Sulzer

headline: ROOSEVELT LIKES THE TICKET.; Says He Hopes Bull Moose Will Vote for It at Primaries.

BULL MOOSE RIOT AND OUST SULZER; Name Full Ticket and Devote Their Platform to Barnes and Murphy. DAVENPORT FOR GOVERNOR "Invite" Colby to Run for U.S. Senate and Seabury for Court of Appeals. DERIDE "SAME OLD BILL" "Proved Crook" and "Faker" Some of the Epithets Applied to Him ;- His Friends Threaten.
leadPara: UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- They threw William Sulzer down hard at the meeting of the Progressive State Committee held here this afternoon. They had a good, old-fashioned Bull Moose time over it, too, in the course of which such epithets as "crook" and "faker" were mixed very freely with Mr. Sulzer's name by some of the Progressive speakers.

headline: THE DREADFUL PLIGHT OF THE MOOSERS.
leadPara: In the freedom of the forest no bull moose ever had to stand up for three hours and take a talking to from a chattering chipmunk. Furthermore, no chipmunk ever had the staggering audacity to send his friends to a moose conference with instructions to bag the entire outfit and bring them back tamed and obedient to the chipmunk will.

headline: HENNESSY CAMPAIGN OPENS WEDNESDAY; Franklin D. Roosevelt and Probably Col. W.G. Rice to Speak at Cooper Union. SULZER NEEDS SIGNATURES Petition for Place on General Ballot Possible ;- Polk Quits Democratic Executive Committee.

headline: FINANCIAL MARKETS; Very Good Bank Showing, Cash Holdings Showing Substantial Increase.
leadPara: Progressive improvement in the banking situation was shown in yesterday's statement of the Clearing House institutions. The outstanding feature of that statement was the decrease of $8,862,000 in the deficit reported the previous week, improvement in this respect having now been shown for two successive weeks.

headline: " TWILIGHT SLEEP" IS SUCCESSFUL IN 120 CASES HERE; Physicians at the Jewish Maternity Hospital Declare That the Freiburg Method of Treating Confinement Cases Is the Ideal One. Distinguished American Obstetricians Oppose this View.
leadPara: THE procedure to effect painless childbirth, devised and carried out at Freiburg, Germany, and designated by the physicians in charge at the Frauenklinik of the Baden University there as "Dammerschiaf," which, being translated, means "the twilight sleep," has had a fair trial extending over a period of several months at the Jewish Maternity Hospital, 270 East Broadway, New York City.

headline: ART AT HOME AND ABROAD; Activity in Artistic Planning of Cities Both Here and in Foreign Countries Likely to Follow Europe's Great War. Most American Cities Need Revision of Their Original Plans, Says Expert ;- Washington and Buffalo Striking Exceptions.
leadPara: WHEN the European war is over one thing may be expected with a reasonable degree of certainty: a brisk renewal of interest in the planning and replanning of cities. European cities for a number of years have had for their inhabitants and for visitors a double charm, that of well-guarded antiquity on the one hand and of aesthetic and scientific modernity on the other.

headline: McDONOGH FOR U.S. SENATE; Bronx Lawyer Files Petition with 5,000 Signatures.

headline: BARNES ELIMINATES HIMSELF AS AN ISSUE; He Will Not Serve as State Chairman After Primaries of Sept. 28. MILLS IS A CANDIDATE Chairman's Letter Says He Wants to Remove Only Reason for Bull Moose Party's Existence.
leadPara: William Barnes, Republican State Chairman, yesterday took steps to eliminate himself as an issue in the primaries and the Fall campaign. In a letter addressed to the candidates who will contend in the primaries for the 150 places on the Republican State Committee Mr. Barnes notified them that under no circumstances would he accept re-election to his present position at the head of that committee.
abstract: candidate for Republican State Chairman

headline: LA FOLLETTE MEN BEATEN.; Philipp Named for Governor and McGovern for Senator.

headline: WILLIAM BARNES'S REVENGE.
leadPara: When the Progressive campaign wagon was stocked up at Saratoga last week, the referendum, the recall, the squelching of judicial decisions, and all the other standard Progressive commodities were left in the storehouse and only the Barnes issue was put aboard.
abstract: his revenge, editorial

headline: LIBEL SUIT CAMPAIGN FUEL.; Roosevelt Hopes It Will Be On While Votes Are Being Made.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, Sept. 1. -- Col. Roosevelt will go to New York tomorrow to talk over the State situation with the Progressive Party leaders. It is his present intention to do no campaigning in New York until after the primaries, but then he will go at it with vigor.
abstract: petitions for U. S. Sen. are being circulated, John M. Bowers and County Clerk Schneider head his committee

headline: ANTI-TRUST BILL PASSED BY SENATE; Republicans Join Democrats in Making Majority on Clayton Measure Overwhelming. THE VOTE IS 46 TO 16 Last of President's Legislative Plans for This Session, and Adjournment Is Expected Soon.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The Senate, by the vote of 46 to 16, this afternoon passed the second number on the Administration's anti-trust programme -the Clayton bill supplementing the Sherman act. As has been the case in regard to most of the measures in which the President has particularly interested himself, many Republicans joined with the Democratic majority to make the vote overwhelming.
abstract: Senate passes Clayton bill; provisions

headline: LET M'ANENY LEAD; HENNESSY WILLING; Makes a Condition ;- He Must Fight to Rid Party of Murphy's Control. CALLS GLYNN "SPINELESS" Promises to Show Gross Misgovernment ;- F.O. Roosevelt Not to Withdraw for Gerard.
leadPara: John A. Hennessy, candidate for the nomination for Governor, and one of the leaders of the anti-Murphy Democracy, opened his campaigns at a large mass meeting at Cooper Union last night by offering to withdraw in favor of George W. McAneny, President of the Board of Aldermen, if McAneny would fight Murphy.
abstract: Hennessy offers to withdraw in his favor

headline: ROOSEVELT INSISTS BARNES IS AN ISSUE; Says He Will Control State Organization from "Behind the Screen." SAME AS MURPHY WORKS Sulzer Visits Bull Moose Headquarters and Gets Colonel's Promise to Remain Neutral.
leadPara: Col. Theodore Roosevelt continued his attack upon William Barnes last night in a statement in which he asserted that by retiring from the State Chairmanship of the Republican Party Mr. Barnes had by no means eliminated himself as an issue in the present State campaign.
abstract: Sulzer visits headquarters and gets Roosevelt's promise to remain neutral

headline: SULZER FILES PETITION.; Has 4,400 Signers Who Want Him Bull Moose Candidate.
leadPara: ALBANY, Sept. 3. -- William Sulzer filed petitions containing 4,400 signatures designating him as a candidate for Governor in the Progressive primaries with the Secretary of State today. Dr. Arthur Kozma of the Tenth Assembly District, New York, and Fred H. Wilson, Chairman of the Bureau of Speakers of the Progressive Party, came here with the petitions.
abstract: Alice Latimer George to run his campaign for re-election due to absence in Europe

headline: GLYNN ANSWERS HENNESSY.; Governor Challenges Him to Name One Instance of Graft.
leadPara: ALBANY, Sept. 3. -- Gov. Glynn in a statement issued tonight entered a general denial of the charges made against him by John A. Hennessy at Cooper Union last night.
abstract: wants Roosevelt to return to Republicans

headline: SULZER REPLIES TO GLYNN.; Insists That the Governor, Not He, Was Murphy's Man.
leadPara: Assemblyman William Sulzer takes exception to a statement made by Gov. Glynn in reply to an attack by John A. Hennessy at Cooper Union. Mr. Hennessy called Mr. Glynn "Murphy's Governor.'' Gov. Glynn in his reply said Mr. Murphy, at the Syracuse Convention two years ago, rejected him (Glynn) and had Mr. Sulzer nominated for Governor.
abstract: fought in his own district for Tammany control

headline: POSTAL SAVINGS INCREASE.; Foreigners, Unable to Send Money Abroad, Swell Deposits Here.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The war in Europe has remarkably increased the postal savings system of the United States during the month of August. Complete figures are not available, but telegraphic reports from New York, Brooklyn, Chicago, and Boston show that during August there was in those cities alone a net gain of $1,500,000 in the excess of deposits over withdrawals.
abstract: in N. Y., was taken prisoner in yacht by French warship

headline: GERMANY PREPARES FOR UNPARALLELED SUFFERING; Herr Dernburg, Head of Her Red Cross and Recently Colonial Secretary, Tells of Plans for Mitigating the Horrors of the Greatest War.
leadPara: THAT Germany has no ambitions toward colonial extension, despite the assertions of her enemies to the contrary, was, as far as international politics go, the most important statement made to me by her late Secretary of State for the Colonies, Herr Bernhard Dernburg, who next to the Ambassador, who last Sunday expressed his views at length in THE TIMES, ranks as the most noteworthy German in the United States at present.

headline: MADISON CAWEIN.; HINMAN AND HEDGES WITHHOLD PETITIONS Both Candidates Ready to File Nominating Papers Before Time Expires Tuesday. WHITMAN LISTS CRITICISED John F. Yawger a Candidate for the Republican State Committee in Gruber's District.
leadPara: The time for filing designating petitions on behalf of candidates in the primaries will expire at midnight or Tuesday, but no petitions have been filed on behalf of two of the Republican candidates for the Gubernatorial nomination. Harvey D. Hinman's campaign managers said last night that the Hinman petitions would be filed tomorrow and would carry many more than the 3,000 signatures required. Joe E. Hedges said that his petitions would be filed on Tuesday.
abstract: withholds petition

headline: ROOSEVELT TAKES STUMP IN LOUISIANA; Attacks Both Old Parties, Particularly Wilson Administration, in New Orleans Speech. APPEALS FOR NEW LINE-UP Wants Tariff Democrats There to Desert Traditional Allegiance to a Party Name and Join Progressives.
leadPara: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 7. -- Theodore Roosevelt arrived here today for a two days' speaking trip in Louisiana. His principal address was delivered here tonight in the Opera House. From here he goes to the Third Congressional District of Louisiana, where the campaign between Democrats and Progressives to elect a Congressman is attracting attention.
abstract: Roosevelt tells of cause of rise in price

headline: SAYS GERARD WON'T RUN.; Roosevelt Thinks He Won't Desert His Post to be Murphy's Tool.
abstract: starts fight in Herkimer County

headline: CHARTER MAID HARD DRIVEN TO WIN RAGE; John E. Madden's Filly Makes Coquette Quit Near Finish in Matron Stakes.
abstract: Matron Stakes won by Charter Maid

headline: COLONEL'S WHIRLWIND TRIP; Makes More Than Score of Speeches in Louisiana "Sugar Bowl."
abstract: makes speeches in La. "sugar bowl,"

headline: FIRST TICKETS OUT UNDER PRIMARY LAW; Only Six Anti-Murphy Men in the Field for Democratic State Committee. FILING TIME NOW EXPIRED Glynn Turns In the Biggest List at Albany ;- Gerard Named for United States Senator.
leadPara: The final entries of candidates in the primary race were made yesterday in the office of the Secretary of State at Albany and with election boards throughout the State of New York. The various bureaus of the Board of Elections in this city were busier places throughout the day than at any previous time since the board was established.
abstract: primary ticket

headline: PETITIONS FILED IN ALBANY.; Glynn Has Longest List, with More Than 20,000 Names.
leadPara: ALBANY, Sept 8. -- The first lap in New York's new direct primary law was completed at midnight, when the petitions for nominations were filed with the Secretary of State. They came in all shapes and conditions, and it will take the clerks in the election bureaus several days to get the petitions systematized.
abstract: petition filed contains longest list of names, receives new challenge from Hennessy

headline: THE MOOSE AS A FACTOR.
abstract: editorial

headline: MAIL COSTS CONWAY'S PLACE; Petition Received Too Late to Put Him on Primary Ballot.
abstract: petition received too late from T. F. Conway to be put on primary ballot

headline: ELECTION BOARD SWAMPED.; Force of Clerks Doubled to Handle Designating Petitions.
leadPara: The Board of Elections was swamped by the number of designating petitions deposited in the hour preceding midnight on Tuesday, when the period for filing them expired. The work of entering the names of candidates had not been completed by midnight last night, although a double force of clerks was employed.
abstract: force of clerks doubled to handle designating petitions

headline: RUMANIA WITH THE ALLIES.; Ex-Minister Knowles Says She May Lead Italy There.
leadPara: Horace G. Knowles of Wilmington, Del., who was the American Minister to Rumania, Bulgaria, and Servia in 1907 and 1908, is stopping at the Republican Club. He was much interested yesterday in dispatches from the Continent, which indicated that Rumania would throw her weight in the European conflict with the Allies against Germany.
abstract: on position of Rumania in European War

headline: PRAISE FOR OSBORN.; F. D. Roosevelt Applauds His Determination to Quit Murphy's Ship.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, left Washington for New York this afternoon for a speech-making tour of New York State in behalf of his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator. He will be away from Washington until after the primaries and will begin his speechmaking at Buffalo.
abstract: F. D. Roosevelt praises him for giving up State Chairmanship

headline: COLONEL TO AID DEMOCRAT.; Will Stump Pennsylvania for Vance McCormick for Governor.
leadPara: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10. -- "Col. Roosevelt declared to me that if we determined the practical way to defeat bossism in Pennsylvania was to unite on the Democratic candidate for Governor, he would come here and advocate the election of Vance McCormick, the Democratic candidate," said Dean William Draper Lewis, the Colonel's legal adviser and right-hand man in the last Presidential campaign, in an interview tonight.
abstract: to stump for Vance McCormick, Democratic candidate for Gov. in Penn.

headline: COMPLIMENT WINS CORINTHIAN 'CHASE; Horses Take Brush Perfectly in Two-Mile Race at Belmont Park.
leadPara: J. E. Widener's handsome steeplechaser Compliment won the renewal of the Corinthian Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday afternoon from a field of five other 'chasers, all of which stood up and managed to go the whole course without a blunder. It was the first running of the race since 1909, the distance of the course being cut from three miles to two.
abstract: Corinthian 'Chase, by Compliment

headline: ROOSEVELT SILENT ON MEDIATION TALK; Sees Oscar S. Straus, but Neither Will Discuss Peace Plans. HE REPUDIATES INTERVIEWS Says He Had a Great Reception Down South ;- To Stump Middle West for 10 Days After Sept. 20.
abstract: visits Col. Roosevelt, will not discuss peace plan

headline: Article 15 -- No Title
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 10. -- The announcement that Dean Lewis had withdrawn as Progressive nominee for Governor in Pennsylvania was no surprise to Col. Roosevelt. He would not comment on the change tonight, pending official notification, but it is understood on the best authority that it will make no difference in his plans to go into Pennsylvania and stump for the ticket.
abstract: Fred Greiner says situation indicates his nomination

headline: ROOSEVELT IN N.Y. FIGHT.; Plans to Stump State for Bull Moose Ticket In October.
leadPara: OYSTER, BAY, L.I., Sept. 11. -- Col. Roosevelt is in fine fighting trim for the hard campaigning which is ahead of him. His trip to Louisiana and the rousing reception he received there put new life in the Bull Moose chieftain, and he looks ready for the fray. He spent this afternoon arranging for his Western trip, which will begin on Sept. 20 and last at least ten days.

headline: ONLY NATION WITHOUT EXCUSE FOR BUSINESS PESSIMISM; Col. George Pope, President of the National Association of Manufacturers, Says That Foolish Fears Should Cease and the United States Should Grasp Its Big Business Opportunity.
leadPara: THE incomparable opportunity which now confronts the American business man, in almost every line of effort, should act as a tremendous stimulant to our national prosperity," said Col. George Pope, President of the National Association of Manufacturers, the most important body of its kind in the United States.

headline: DECLARES BARNES CONTROLS ALBANY; Roosevelt's Plea for Change of Venue for Libel Trial ;- Judge Reserves Decision. VENIRE DRAWN BY GRATTAN County Clerk Described as Barnes Henchman ;- Fair Trial Impossible, It Is Alleged ;- Barnes's Answer.
leadPara: ALBANY, Sept. 12. -- Decision was reserved today by Supreme Court Justice Chester on the motion of Theodore Roosevelt's attorneys to have the $50,000 suit for alleged libel brought against him by Republican State Chairman William Barnes tried outside of Albany County, Mr. Barnes's home.
abstract: fourteen present to hear him

headline: SCHOOLS WILL OPEN WITH 750,000 PUPILS; Additional Buildings, Ready for Occupancy, Will Increase Sittings 12,727. MOST TEACHERS ARE READY Per Capita Cost of Educating Child Was $40.24 in 1913, as Against $34.12 in 1911.
leadPara: The public schools will reopen Monday with every prospect of the busiest and most progressive year in the history of the Board of Education. Last year the board handled 720,000 school children, this year the board will probably take care of 750,000 pupils. The registration of pupils began last Wednesday, but the actual result will not be known until Monday.
abstract: Ackerman, Carl F.

headline: ROOSEVELT NEUTRAL EVEN IN WAR TALK; Confers with Oscar Straus Again, Presumably About Mediation. IS THE KAISER'S FRIEND Belief at Oyster Bay That Colonel Would Be a Valuable Factor in Any Mediation Plan.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 13. -- Oscar S. Straus, American member of The Hague Tribunal, who, according to the news dispatches from Washington, has been endeavoring to bring about some plan for ending the European conflict, was the guest of Col. Roosevelt at Sagamore Hill for several hours today.
abstract: editorial

headline: THE MAINE ELECTION.
leadPara: Maine is the last of the September States, once relied upon to give an indication by their Fall elections how the country would go in November. Her State election will be held today, and, as it will be the only one before November, it will be watched by all politicians for whatever it may show concerning the state of public feeling.

headline: GERMANY'S SIDE OF THE WAR ISSUES SET FORTH BY AN OFFICIAL SPOKESMAN; Dr. Dernburg, Former Colonial Secretary, Defends the Kaiser, Says War Was Inevitable, and Discusses How Peace Can Come.
leadPara: When I arrived in New York a fortnight ago, I was greatly surprised on reading in the papers big headlines such as "The Kaiser's War," "The Kaiser's Army," "The Kaiser Beaten," I thought at first that this was only a sort of abbreviation and that the "Kaiser's" name stood as a symbol for the whole of Germany in this war forced upon our nation.
abstract: Germany's side of the issues, special article reprinted from The Sun

headline: HENNESSY'S NAME LEADS.; Hedges Draws First Place on Republican Primary Ballot.
leadPara: ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- The organization candidates of the dominant political parties had to take secondary places on the primary ballots at the drawing for places in the Secretary of State's office today. John A. Hennessy drew first place on the Democratic ballot for Governor, which made Gov. Glynn's place second.
abstract: party defeated in elections

headline: JUDICIARY FUSION PLAN IS DROPPED; Republicans and Bull Moose to Unite on Candidates Below Fourteenth Street. BATES QUITS FOR MILLS Lynch Is Off Democratic Slate for City Court and Allen Is Named.
leadPara: Fusion between Republicans and Progressives on Judgships was discussed last night by groups of leaders at both Progressive and Republican county headquarters. Two nominations for the Supreme Court in New York County and two places on the bench of the City Court were involved in the deal which was being proposed.
abstract: to unite with Republicans for judiciary candidates below 14th St.

headline: DEMOCRATS LEAD IN MAINE VOTING; Curtis Apparently Elected Governor, Probably by 600 Plurality ;- Legislature Close. PROGRESSIVE VOTE SMALL Congressional Delegation May Not Change, Although First District Is in Doubt. ISSUE OF WILSON POLICIES Democrats Fought Their Campaign on That Line ;- Heaviest Voting In State In Years.
leadPara: BANGOR, Me., Sept. 14. -- Present returns indicate that Oakley C. Curtis, Democrat, Mayor of Portland, was today elected Governor of Maine. Returns from the cities of Bangor and Portland just before midnight changed an indicated Republican plurality for Governor to an apparent Democratic victory, though the result will not be certain until fifty missing towns have been heard from.
abstract: Curtis elected Gov., Legislature to be controlled by party

headline: LAST DECLINATIONS FILED.; Election Board Notified by Those Who Refuse to Run.
leadPara: Persons who had been put up unwillingly for nominations in the primaries or who had reconsidered their determination to run filed declinations last night at the office of the Board of Elections in the Municipal Building as follows:

headline: STATE BOARD OPENS FIRE ON KINGSBURY; Investigates Hiring of 47 Examiners Who Had Not Passed Civil Service Test. WON'T ADMIT HIS COUNSEL Rumor Says Municipal Commission May Be Removed with Approval of Gov. Glynn.

Kingsbury, Commissioner of Charities, was called before the State Civil Service Commission yesterday to explain the employment by his department of forty-seven examiners who had not passed the civil service examination, yet had been approved by the Municipal Civil Service Commission, he was unable to obtain admission for Assistant Corporation Counsel Stover as his legal representative and a stenographer.

headline: BLEASE'S SEDAN.
leadPara: Bleaseism has not merely been defeated: it has been wiped out. South Carolina took a long time in coming to her senses, but her reformation consisted in the utter destruction of the regime of vulgarity and indecency that had ruled her so long. Every candidate who was allied with or supported by BLEASE was not only beaten, but snowed under.
abstract: Blease's Sedan, editorial

headline: MAINE STILL FOR WILSON.
leadPara: The election in Maine was as fair a test of public sentiment as could he afforded. There was the usual mixture of State and national issues, but on State issues alone there was no reason to expect an overturn. The Republican Administration had not been such as to arouse any general dissatisfaction, and on State issues alone might have counted on retaining power.
abstract: Maine still for Wilson, editorial

headline: BIG POW-WOW ON SULZER.; If He Gets Nomination Many Bull Moose Will Quit Party.
leadPara: A big Progressive pow-wow is planned for today to determine what attitude the Bull Moose Party organization should maintain toward the candidacy of William Sulzer. He is not an enrolled Progressive. As an Assemblyman he is not listed as a Progressive but as a Progressive Democrat.

headline: WHITNEY HORSES BEATEN AT BELMONT; Meeting House, Virile, and Gainer Each Finish Second in Their Races.
abstract: summary

headline: WHITMAN PLEDGES GIVEN BY FIVE CLUBS; "Fighting District Attorney" Campaigns with Chairman Koenig. PROMISED ALL THE VOTES Resolutions to Give Him Primary Support Unanimously Adopted by Republicans.
leadPara: Introduced as "the Fighting District Attorney" and received everywhere with applause, Charles S. Whitman last night spoke in five Republican clubs in lower Manhattan. After his speech in each clubroom a resolution pledging the enrolled Republicans of the district to support him for Governor in the Republican primaries was proposed and unanimously carried.

headline: THE PROGRESSIVES.
leadPara: So much emphasis has been laid on the falling off in the Progressive vote that it is well to consider what it means and how it affects the political situation. To conclude that such an event as the Maine election should give encouragement to the Republicans by showing that the Progressives are not a factor of importance is to take a superficial view and to ignore the facts.

headline: ROOSEVELT IGNORES SULZER'S CANDIDACY; Signs Appeal to Bull Moose to Support Davenport in Primaries. VOTE ALREADY COUNTED? To Campaign with Davenport In October ;- Hennessy and Hinman to Lose and Thus Aid Moose.

headline: URGES FAIR TEST OF 'TWILIGHT SLEEP'; Results in Banishing Pain, Says Dr. Rongy, Compel Wide Attention. REPORTS ON 125 CASES More Than 80 Per Cent of Patients Remembered Nothing ;- Some Difficulties In Early Experiments.
leadPara: BUFFALO, Sept. 17. -- Dr. A.J. Rongy of New York read a paper here today before the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists on "Twilight Sleep," the scopolamine-morphine method of abolishing pain and memory in labor cases, which is being tried out in various hospitals in the United States, but whose chief advocates are Prof. Kronig and Prof. Gauss of the Frauenklinik at Freiburg, Germany.
abstract: urges fair test of "twilight sleep,"

headline: ANOTHER FREE MARKET.; Borough of Richmond Will Have One in Tomkinsville Square.

It was said yesterday by a man who had inspected the markets that they are in grave danger because of lack of proper supervision.

Roosevelt has blasted the hopes of friends of Edward Carrington, Jr., Republican candidate for United States Senator in Maryland, by a dictum to former Attorney General Bonaparte and Gen. Stuart MacDonald, who have been conferring the last two days with him and George W. Perkins in New York.

Theodore Roosevelt, which, after saying "there are certain States where the Republican candidates have declared they are for me in 1916," goes on to say:

headline: GOV. BALDWIN FOR SENATOR.; Named by Democrats Who Indorse Wilson Administration.
leadPara: HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 18. -- Gov. Simeon E. Baldwin was nominated for United States Senator at the Democratic State Convention here today, defeating Congressman Bryan F. Mahan by a vote of 377 to 225.

leadPara: Col. Roosevelt has been drawn into the local squabble over the Progressive nomination for Representative in the Tenth Congress District, Brooklyn, and has written a stinging letter attacking Reuben L. Haskell, the Republican candidate, who has also received a Bull Moose indorsement.
abstract: Roosevelt advises bolt on Haskell, says he never promised neutrality to Sulzer

headline: CONSTITUTION; Mr. Benson's View That It Is Dishonest OUR DISHONEST CONSTITUTION. By Allan L. Benson. New York: B. W. Huebsch. $1
leadPara: NOT long ago Prof. Beard of Columbia wrote a book upon the United States Constitution which was among the "one hundred best" of THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK REVIEW'S list, and which was duly noticed before that list was compiled. Upon Prof. Beard's text Mr. Benson has embroidered his sermon.

headline: Big Meeting in Hutchinson.

ROOSEVELT SPEAKS FOR KANSAS MOOSE; Oldtime Welcome for Colonel at Wichita ;- Big Audience Hears His Address. HITS COLORADO COAL CO. Couples Strike with New Haven to Show Alleged Breakdown of Control of Labor and Capital.
leadPara: WICHITA, Kan., Sept. 19. -- Theodore Roosevelt received a leader's welcome in Wichita this morning when he stepped from his special car. Three thusand persons shouted "Hello, Teddy!" The Colonel smiled, took off his hat, and bowed.

headline: WIDENER 'CHASERS FIRST AND THIRD; Philadelphia Horses Account for Both Money Ends of the Brook Cup Handicap.
leadPara: Joseph E. Widener came from Philadelphia yesterday to see his steeplechasers Compliment and Relluf run in the Brook Cup Handicap, over the two-and-a-half-mile course. Last night he took back with him the solid gold cup worth $2,500 and its replica in silver, worth $250, and $1,100 in cash, which the horses won by running first and third in the race.

headline: ATTACKS WHITMAN ON VOTING RECORD; Lucien Bonheur Alleges the Candidate Told Him He Supported Roosevelt in 1912. NOT "ALWAYS REPUBLICAN" District Attorney Denies Charge and Says Colonel Never Promised to Back Him for Mayor.
leadPara: Lucien Bonheur, a prominent Progressive who a year ago was the active head of a movement to get the Progressive indorsement for District Attorney Whitman in his Mayoralty boom, came out with a statement yesterday in which he declared that Mr. Whitman at that time had told both him and Col. Roosevelt that he had voted for the Colonel for President in 1912.

headline: HEDGES MEN ACCUSE KOENIG AND BARNES; State Chairman Says a Ballot for Hedges Is a Ballot for Hinman. APPEAL TO "SILENT VOTE" Candidate Charges Two Leaders Are Intimidating Lesser Leaders in Primary Campaign.
leadPara: During the closing week of the primary campaign Job E. Hedges, candidate for the Gubernatorial nomination in the Republican primaries, will make his appeal solely to the "silent and unattached" vote. This was determined at a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Hedges Campaign Committee last night.
abstract: says a ballot for Hedges is a ballot for Hinman

headline: ROOSEVELT IN MISSOURI.; Will Continue His Speech-Making Tour for Progressives Today.

headline: FIRST AID TO FRAUD.
leadPara: Whether intentionally or not, the primary law was drawn so as to make honest fusion hard and crooked fusion easy. The case which has come to light in the Tenth Congressional District in Brooklyn is doubtless only one of many which have not excited attention. The law facilitates dishonest deals between local bosses of different parties and is a distinct incitement to bribery.
abstract: editorial

headline: WHITMAN RIDDLES GLYNN'S 'ECONOMY'; Tells Brooklyn Republicans the Governor Juggled the Figures. NO SAVING OF $11,000,000 He Quotes Official Records in Speeches in Eight Kings Assembly Districts.
leadPara: District Attorney Whitman, candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, addressed crowded meetings at eight different Republican Clubs in Brooklyn last night. He was enthusiastically received everywhere. He said with frankness that he personally believed he would be nominated by an overwhelming majority at the primaries next Monday.
abstract: A. S. Dulin says treasury is low

headline: KILL HARBOR BILL AFTER WEEK'S FIGHT; Pork Barrel Measure Distributing $34,000,000 Is Sent Back to Committee. BURTON VANQUISHES FOES Leader of Long Attack ;- Substitute Bill Must Appropriate Only $20,000,000 ;- Senate Plans Economy.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- By fighting for more than a week the allied filibustering forces in the Senate slowly but surely worked their way toward the intrenched advocates of the River and Harbor ("pork barrel") bill until tonight they made a final rush, overwhelmed their foes, and forced them to unconditional surrender.
abstract: Sen. Pomerene, after conference with Pres. Wilson, urges economy; bill sent back to committee

headline: ROOSEVELT DRAWS CROWDS; Tells Missourians That Whisky Is Usually Ally of Crooked Politics.
leadPara: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 21. -- Col. Theodore Roosevelt spoke in Kansas City, Mo., at noon today, and in Kansas City, Kan., just across the State line, tonight. In both places the halls swore crowded, and at the noon meeting all the near-by streets were thronged.
abstract: tells Missourians that whisky is ally of crooked politics

headline: ROOSEVELT IN NEBRASKA.; Democrats Help Draw Crowd, but There Is a Reason.

headline: HEDGES USES QUIGG TO ATTACK WHITMAN; Declares He Knows of Frequent Telephone Talks Between Them. SUGGESTS JOHN DOE QUIZ Tells of "Best Publicity Agent" and Col. Roosevelt in Conference on District Attorney.
leadPara: At the Seventh Assembly District Republican Club, Eighth Avenue and Twenty-third Street last night Job E. Hedges talked, of Lemuel E. Quigg's alleged Connection with Charles S. Whitman's campaign for the nomination for Governor. Hedges Styled Quigg "New York's best publicity 'agent," and said that Frederick C. Tanner, Whitman's manager, did not know of Quigg's connection with-the Whitman campaign.

headline: HINMAN QUESTIONS WHITMAN ON BARNES; Reply Is That State Chairman's Domination Ends Next Monday. McKNIGHT ATTACKS HIM Mr. Barnes Says He Only Retained His Leadership to Oppose Roosevelt Fallacies.
leadPara: In attempting again to force William Barnes, Jr., the Republican State Chairman, to the front as the main issue, ex-State Senator Harvey D. Hinman brought about a three-cornered wrangle yesterday which served to enliven the primary campaign. Mr. Hinman dictated by long distance telephone from the western part of the State three questions, which he called upon Mr. Whitman to answer.

leadPara: SARATOGA, Sept. 23. -- The Appellate Division, Third Department, today upheld the decision of Supreme Court Justice Chester in Albany dismissing the proceeding instituted by Walter L. Rathborne in an attempt to have Frederick M. Davenport's name removed from the primary ballot as a Progressive candidate for Governor.

headline: Article 13 -- No Title
leadPara: GALESBURG, Ill., Sept. 24. -- In his Address here Col. Roosevelt deplored blind adherence to names rather than to principles. He said that talk of Progressive return to either of the old parties was absurd.

headline: Article 14 -- No Title
leadPara: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 24. -- The application of the anti-trust law in recent years had been a failure because of a tendency to attack ineffectively big industries which have done wrong, meanwhile harassing honest business effectively, was charged by Col. Roosevelt in his speech here tonight.

headline: ROOSEVELT ASSAILS BLIND PARTY FEALTY; Deplores, in Illinois, Adherence to Names Rather Than Principles. MOOSE RETURN ABSURD Great Crowds Turn Out for Colonel's Speeches ;- He Assails Sullivan and Sherman.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- Immense throngs greeted Col. Theodore Roosevelt today when he began a two days' campaign in behalf of Raymond Robins, Senatorial candidate of the Progressive Party of Illinois. Entering the State at Rock Island, Col. Roosevelt spoke to 5,000 people in that city.

headline: DAVENPORT ADMITS CRISIS FOR MOOSE; If Sulzer Wins, the Progressive Party Will Go Out of Business, He Asserts. ROOSEVELT TOLD HIM SO Candidate Tells Bronx Audience exGovernor is a Demagogue "with a Group of Star Freaks."

headline: WAR REVENUE BILL PASSES THE HOUSE; Eleven Democrats and One Progressive Line Up with Republicans Against the Measure. FIGHT IN SENATE EXPECTED Minority Leaders Believe They Can Delay It ;- Higher Treasury Receipts Explained.

headline: SULZER AS A ZOOLOGIST.; Says Davenport Goes Backward, and, Therefore, Is a Crab.

leadPara: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 26. -- Yale's football team, playing a wide-open offensive game, and using many sensational forward passes behind deceptive formations, had no trouble in defeating the University of Maine 20 to 0 in the opening game of the season today.

headline: LAST FIGURES SHOW ALL CANDIDATES WIN; Hennessy Says Murphy's Own County Won't Beat Him by More Than 10,000. SULZER SURE OF VICTORY Hinman and Whitman Managers Express Confidence in Result, but Hedges Is Silent.

headline: RESULTS OF PRIMARIES; As Indicated by Returns Received Up to 3:30 A.M. Today. HINMAN'S DEFEAT CRUSHING Vote in City and State Was Light, Democrats 34, Republicans 40 Per Cent. BULL MOOSE SHOW POORLY Whitman Vote in City Not a Barnes Victory, for Calder Ran Far Ahead of Wadsworth. GLYNN, WHITMAN, GERARD, WADSWORTH
leadPara: Yesterday's primary election, the first in which the people of New York ever nominated their candidates directly, resulted in the nomination for Governor of Martin H. Glynn by the Democrats, with 111,760 majority; Charles S. Whitman by the Republicans, with 67,421, and Frederick M. Davenport by the Progressives, with 1,256.

Wadsworth for United States Senator over William M. Calder in the Republican primaries.

Hinman, who fought for the Republican nomination for Governor in the primaries on the anti-Barnes issue, and bitterly attacked District Attorney Whitman as the candidate of Barnes, buried the hatchet last night, and announced that he would throw his support to Mr. Whitman in the coming campaign.

headline: BANKERS OBJECT TO CURRENCY TAX; Supposed It Would Increase to Accord with Time Bank's Allotment Was Outstanding. OPPOSE TREASURY RULING Law, They Believe, Contemplated a Tax on Each Issue Based on the Time It Was In Circulation.
leadPara: Considerable discussion has been caused among officers of national banks in this city by the receipt of a ruling by John Burke, Treasurer of the United States, on the manner in which the tax on so-called emergency currency is to be levied. The tax is progressive, increasing from 3 per cent. a year for the first three months to 6 per cent. a year for the ninth month and thereafter.

Within the next few weeks spokesmen of the Administration will be in the field supporting Democratic nominees.

headline: Letter to the Editor 2 -- No Title

PRESIDENT WRITES POLITICAL LETTERS; Senators Shively and Chamberlain Indorsed for Re-Election ;- Will Support Others. CABINET TO TAKE STUMP Bryan Will Make Western Trip, but Will Skip Roger Sullivan's State ;- No Speeches by Wilson.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The political pot began to boil in Washington today. Activity was particularly noticeable in Administration circles. President Wilson wrote letters, which were made public, indorsing Senators Chamberlin of Oregon and Shively of Indiana and the whole Indiana Congressional delegation, which is solidly Democratic. In addition, it was made known that Secretary Bryan and other members of the Cabinet would go on the stump in behalf of candidates of the Democratic Party.
abstract: Sen. Chamberlain indorsed for re-election by Pres. Wilson

headline: REPUBLICANS ELECT TANNER CHAIRMAN; He Rushed Back from Philadelphia to Decline, and They Accepted. MILLS QUIT FOR WHITMAN New State Committee Organized After a Day of Differences Finally Adjusted Smoothly.
leadPara: Frederick C. Tanner, who managed District Attorney Whitman's primary campaign, was elected Chairman of the Republican State Committee yesterday to succeed William Barnes. There was much pulling and hauling before this was accomplished, and Mr. Whitman finally was forced to call up Ogden L. Mills on the telephone and request him to abandon his candidacy for the place. Nothing less than a personal request from the candidate for Governor would have made Mr. Mills quit.
abstract: concedes defeat, offers to help Wadsworth in campaign

headline: ROOSEVELT ASSAILS 'POLITICAL GUNMEN'; In Philadelphia Speech He Likens Corrupt Bosses to Underworld Gangsters. 12,000 OUT TO GREET HIM Penrose, In Counter-Attack, Says the Colonel Never Can Be Elected President Again.
leadPara: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- Theodore Roosevelt, opening his campaign in Pennsylvania against machine domination of politics tonight in the First Regiment Armory, demanded the overthrow of Senator Boies Penrose, and pleaded for the election of Gifford Pinchot and Vance C. McCormick, the Democratic Fusion candidate for Governor.
abstract: likens corrupt bosses to underworld gangsters, Penrose answers him, pleads for election of Pinchot and Vance C. McCormick

headline: PRESIDENT EXTENDS HIS AID IN OHIO; Campaigning by Letter, He Lauds Gov. Cox and His Record. CABINET TO TAKE STUMP Bryan's Tour Significantly Omits Illinois ;- Daniels Will Take a Wide Swing ;- He Compliments Glynn.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- President Wilson's political letter-writing campaign in aid of Democratic candidates for elective offices touched Ohio today. The President's contribution was a letter to Representative George White of that State, indorsing the administration of Gov. Cox, who is a candidate for re-election.
abstract: Sec. Daniels compliments Glynn, headquarters opened for Gerard, T. D. McCarthy in charge, McCombs may become State Chairman

headline: BRYCE DEFENDS WAR FOR TREATIES; A Statement, for Neutrals, of England's Case Against Germany. ASSAILS BERNHARDI THEORY As Tending to the Extinction of Small Nations and Their Culture. NOT EVEN TRULY GERMAN Ex-Ambassador Says the Kaiser's Subjects Generally Do Not Subscribe to It.
leadPara: LONDON, Oct. 3. The present war has had some unexpected consequences. headline: CLAYTON BILL GOES THROUGH SENATE; Upper Body Indorses Last of Anti-Trust Measures, 35 to 24. HOUSE WILL PASS TODAY Effort to Recommit the Measure Results In Final Defeat for Its Opponents.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The enactment of the last bill on the President's revised anti-trust programme came in sight when the Senate this afternoon, by a vote of 35 to 24, adopted the conference report on the Clayton measure supplementing the Sherman ect. The report has still to be accepted in the House, but under the cloture rules of that chamber it probably will be rushed to adoption tomorrow.

headline: REPUBLICAN REBUILDERS.
leadPara: After almost twenty years of power the Republican Party underwent in 1912 the most humiliating defeat ever inflicted in American politics; it carried only two States, Utah and Vermont, both of them among the smallest in the Electoral College. headline: SAYS AUSTRIA HAD TO DEFEND HERSELF; Dr. Fischerauer, Vice Consul Here, Insists His Government Was Forced Into War. PUTS BLAME ON RUSSIA Compelled to Fight or Surrender to the Forces of Sedition, He Tells Twilight Club.
leadPara: Dr. Fritz Fischerauer, the AustroHungarian Vice Consul in New York, in a speech he made to the members of the Twilight Club, at 107 West Fortyfourth Street, last night, defended his Emperor and country's course in the present war. He said he did not believe the people of this country would condemn Austria-Hungary "for preferring war to an abdication of its sovereignty and a surrender to the forces of sedition and barbarism."

headline: ART AT HOME AND ABROAD
leadPara: THIS week, Oct. 15, 16, and 17 there will be an exhibition of the recent work done in art by the pupils of the city high schools.
