headline: Article 11 -- No Title
leadPara: DENVER, Col., Oct. 12. -- Gov. E. M. Ammons was at Wichita, Kan., today attending the International Dry Farming Congress. His most recent statement regarding the proposed withdrawal of the Federal troops from the strike district was that the ability of the State to take care of the situation depended on the sale of the $1,000,000 bonds voted by the Legislature last May for the payment of the military debt.

headline: FINANCIAL MARKETS; Committee Calls for Gold from Out-of-Town Banks ;- Curb to Open.
leadPara: The first call upon out-of-town institutions for a delivery of gold subscribed to the $100,000,000 pool was sent out yesterday. It asked for 25 per cent. of the subscriptions, and the effect of the arrival of this money will probably be seen in the bank statement at the close of this week. So far the influence of the pool's sales of exchange has been out of proportion to the amount awarded applicants.
abstract: Commissioner Osborn sends inquiries to bankers to ascertain the amount of Amer. securities now held abroad

headline: SCORNS A STRAIGHT TICKET.; Faithful Party Man the Boss's Great Asset, Says Roosevelt
leadPara: COOPERSTOWN, Oct. 13. -- Col. Theodore Roosevelt and Frederick M. Davenpork, the Progressive candidate for Governor, spoke in the Village Hall this afternoon to a crowd that packed all the seats and standing room. From here they went to Oneonta, where there was a rousing night meeting of Moose and their sympathizers.
abstract: scorns a straight ticket

headline: GUTHRIE ATTACKS GERARD AS A JUDGE; "Lacking in Learning, Impartiality, and Dignity," Lawyer Says. SUBSERVIENT TO TAMMANY' Senator Root, Whitman, and Wadsworth Other Speakers at Union League Club's Meeting.
leadPara: The men who made the principal speeches at the reception tendered to to the Republican State candidates and their friends at the Union League Club last night were William D. Guthrie, the lawyer, and Senator Elihu Root. Mr. Guthrie's speech was mainly a prolonged and bitter attack upon James W. Gerard, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator.
abstract: Guthrie attacks Gerard as Judge

headline: NEW WHITMAN ISSUE IS HIGHWAY GRAFT; "Do You Approve of Bensel?" He Demands of Gov. Glynn in Brooklyn. QUOTES OSBORN'S REPORT Scathingly Reviews the State Roads Scandals ;- Says the Governor Took No Action to Punish.
leadPara: District Attorney Whitman opened his campaign for Governor in Brooklyn last night, making two addresses there and one at Richmond Hill, L.I. He was enthusiastically received at each place and listened to attentively. His largest and most enthusiastic audience greeted him at 92 Herkimer Street, where 2,500 persons had crowded into Kismet Temple and had waited an hour for him to appear.
abstract: attacked by Whitman for lack of action in highway graft and Bensel

headline: Roosevelt in Jersey Campaign.

ROOSEVELT LASHES OLD PARTY MACHINES; Tells Syracuse Voters That Neither Whitman Nor Glynn Shows Any Independence. BARNES AND MURPHY AS ONE Colby Ridicules Guthrie's Stand for Wadsworth and Praises Gerard's Record as Judge.
leadPara: SYRACUSE, Oct. 14. -- Col. Theodore Roosevelt and Bainbridge Colby, the Progressive nominee for United States Senator, continued their attacks upon the two old parties here tonight. Col. Roosevelt pounded away at District Attorney Whitman and went into more detail about the working agreement which, he said, existed between the Republican organization of New York State and Tammany.
abstract: attacked by Bainbridge Colby

headline: DENIES MOOSE SLUMP.; Leader Lesser of the Thirty-first Says Party Is Still Active.

headline: ONLY ONE MOOSE TICKET.; Rhode Island Court Denies Hartford Wing Place on Ballot.

headline: WILSON INDORSES GLYNN'S CANDIDACY; "You Have Acted with Candor and Directness in Cause of Progressive Legislation." McANENY TO SUPPORT HIM City Counsel Polk and J.N. Wallace Praise Governor Also ;- Many Tributes to Gerard.

headline: WHITMAN ASSAILS GLYNN INDORSERS; Those Who Pounded Governor and Sulzer See Things Differently Now, He Says. DOESN'T FEAR WILSON PLEA Chairman Tanner Says It Is a Sign of Panic and Voters Will Resent Outside Interference.
leadPara: Organizations and individuals who have indorsed the candidacy of Gov. Martin H. Glynn were assailed by District Attorney Whitman in an address delivered at 6 o'clock last evening at the opening of the headquarters of the Whitman College Men's League at 1S East Forty-first Street.

headline: FIRST ELECTION OF SENATORS BY THE PEOPLE.
leadPara: More than one-third of the Senate are to be elected on Nov. 3, and it will be the first time in the history of the country when all the Senators chosen have been elected by popular vote. Outside the South there is a vigorous contest going on for nearly every Senatorship involved.
abstract: editorial

headline: NEW ROOSEVELT CHARGE.; Says, Whitman Violated Pledge to Committee of One Hundred.
leadPara: ROCHESTER, Oct. 16. -- Col. Roosevelt charged here tonight that District Attorney Whitman, by appointing a Tammany adherent as one of his assistants, violated a solemn promise he made in 1909 in accepting the indorsement of the Committee of One Hundred. The Colonel got a hearty reception upon his arrival with Frederick M. Davenport, the Progressive nominee for Governor.
abstract: Glynn taunts him on nomination in 1913 by Tammany, Roosevelt says he violated pledge to Committee of One Hundred, primary expenditures, says he will win, repeats his question about Bensel

headline: MUDDY FIELD MAY CHECK NOTRE DAME; Famous Forward-Pass Team at New Haven to Play Yale Today.
leadPara: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16. -- Because of the unexpected improvement in physical condition of Aleck Wilson, Coach Frank Hinkey this afternoon chose him to begin the game against Notre Dame tomorrow, one of Yale's most exacting contests of the season. Wilson has not been in a scrimmage since he was injured in the game with Virginia two weeks ago, and donned his uniform for the first time two days ago.

headline: Col. Roosevelt in Chicago on Monday
WHAT CAUSES SLIPS OF THE TONGUE? WHY DO WE FORGET?; Prof. Sigmund Freud, the Noted Viennese Psychologist, Has Interesting Theories About the Unconscious Motives in Our Everyday Activities.
leadPara: A WEALTHY but not very generous host once invited some friends to an evening dance. About midnight there was an intermission in the music, presumably for supper. All the guests were very hungry and looked forward to a hearty meal, hoping that on this occasion their host had overcome his usual stinginess.

headline: BELGIUM'S "GRAY PAPER" SHOWS HER PART IN DIPLOMATIC NEGOTIATIONS CONCERNING THE WAR; Full Text of the Collection of Official Documents Published by the Ministry for Foreign Affairs Covering the Period from July 24th to Aug. 29th, 1914. headline: GOV. WALSH TAKES STUMP.; Massachusetts Executive Reviews Administration in Campaign Speech.
leadPara: BOSTON. Oct. 17. -- Gov. David I. Walsh, seeking re-election, gave an account tonight of his administration in his first speech of the campaign. He declared that "the cost of the State Government has been kept $1,250,000 less than the lowest figures made by the Republican State Auditor at the commencement of the administration this year."
abstract: Atty. Gen. Parsons brings action to annul its charter

headline: WAR TAX BILL PASSES SENATE; Democrats Check Revolt and Put Measure Through by Vote of 34 to 22. COTTON MEN ARE DEFEATED Vice President Rules Out Their Motion to Table Bill When Their Amendment Is Lost. MAY RAISE $107,000,000 Minimum Estimate of Revenue from the New Taxes Is $92,000,000 ;- Now Goes to Conference. WAR TAX BILL PASSES SENATE

headline: " No MIDDLEMEN FOR FARM PRODUCTS IN EUROPE"; David Lubin Describes the Way in Which Distribution of Food Supplies Is Made Direct to Continental Consumers by National Marketing Commissions.
leadPara: THE United States has "national bodies" of farmers, unwieldy, incoherent masses, mainly influenced by heterogeneous ideas, who seldom know what is to be done or what is not to be done. Their status reminds me of a story. The San Francisco Argonaut came out with a query, "What is a Populist?" It said: "It is a hard question; we will try to answer it next issue."

headline: PRESIDENT PROUD OF 63D CONGRESS; Legislation Enacted Frees Business from Monopoly, He Writes Mr. Underwood. CONFIDENT OF ELECTIONS Declares Voters Never Failed to Reward Service ;- Change "Would Set Clock Back." OUTLINES NEXT PROGRAMME Merchant Marine and Conservation ;- Underwood Gives Credit to Wilson's "Magnificent Leadership." PRESIDENT PROUD OF 63D CONGRESS
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- In a letter to Representative Oscar W. Underwood, leader of the Democratic majority in the House of Representatives, President Wilson congratulates Congress upon the legislation enacted since the incoming of the present Administration. The letter is Mr. Wilson's principal contribution to the political campaign this year, when the entire membership of the House and one-third of the membership of the Senate is to be elected.
abstract: letter to Repr. Underwood congratulating Congress on legislation enacted and outlining next programme

headline: ATTACKS MITCHEL FOR BACKING GLYNN; "You Cannot Hand Over Your Supporters Blindfold," Tanner Writes. ASKS MAYOR ABOUT BENSEL Says He Has Abandoned Anti-Tammany Fight and Asks if He Will Vote for "Wm. H. Sohmer."
leadPara: Frederick C. Tanner, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, sent to Mayor Mitchel yesterday an open letter charging him with having abandoned his fight against Charles F. Murphy and Tammany Hall, and asking him if he intended to support John A. Bensel for State Engineer and William Sohmer for Controller, and John F. Ahearn and Louis Haffen for delegates to the Constitutional Convention on the Glynn ticket.
abstract: attacks Mitchel for backing Glynn

headline: SURE HE WILL BE ELECTED GOVERNOR; James E. Ferguson, Democratic Nominee, Leaves Texas Campaign for Business Visit Here. GIVES PLEDGE TO WILSON Assures President That State Will Strongly Support Administration ;- Cotton Situation Improving.
abstract: says he is sure he will be elected Gov. of Texas, gives pledge to Wilson, says cotton situation is improving

headline: POLK IS OUT FOR GERARD.; Secretary Lane and Senator Simmons Indorse Ambassador.
leadPara: Another member of President Wilson's Cabinet, Franklin K. Lane, Secretary of the Interior, has come out with a strong indorsement of Ambassador James W. Gerard, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, and so has Senator F.M. Simmons of North Carolina, Chairman of the Finance Committee. In a letter to John M. Bowers, Chairman of the Gerard Campaign Committee, Secretary Lane wrote:
abstract: arrested for election fraud

headline: CHICAGO CHURCH FIRED.; Second Outrage in a Few Days Causes $40,000 Damage.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- A second attempt to destroy a Roman Catholic Church by fire within a few days caused a loss today of more than $40,000 to the Church of St. Charles Borromeo, at West Twelfth and Cypress Streets. The organ, which cost $20,000, is absolutely destroyed, as are many of the furnishings of the church.
abstract: says City Inquiry Bureau is wrong in attacking Board of Estimate Budget

headline: ROOSEVELT BLOCKED DEAL FOR SENATE; Reveals Overtures Made to the Illinois Moose in the Famous 1913 Fight. ATTACK ON WADSWORTH Digresses in Chicago Speech to Assail Murphy and Barnes and Old Parties Here.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- Col. Theodore Roosevelt wound up a two days' speaking trip in Illinois in the interest of the Progressive candidates with an address here tonight, in which he digressed to pay his respects at length to the Republican and Democratic leaders of New York State.
abstract: Roosevelt speaks in favor of Robins and attacks Roger and Sullivan, tells of blocking a Senate deal

headline: AS BAD AS THE DEMOCRATS.
leadPara: What hope have the Republicans to hold out for the salvation of the country from the dreadful condition in which the Wilson policies and the Democratic Congress have plunged it? All these measures have been passed by Republican votes as well as by Democratic votes. Some of them have been passed by a unanimous Republican vote.
abstract: editorial

headline: WHITMAN ON INSPECTION EVIL.; Glynn Blamed by Opponent for Keeping Tammany Men in Jobs.
leadPara: SYRACUSE, Oct. 20. -- District Attorney Whitman's tour led him today through territory that had gone heavily for Harvey D. Hinman, his Republican antagonist for the Gubernatorial nomination at the primaries. Mr. Whitman spoke in Ontario, Yates, Seneca, and Cayuga Counties.

He was President of the St. Luke's Society, an organization which conducted an establishment in which Alderman "Blind Billy" Kent and others lost their lives in a fire in 1902. Miller and his manager were held and subjected to severe censure.

Mitchell Palmer, Penrose's Democratic opponent, for the Senate.
abstract: Pres. Wilson to support Palmer

headline: COLD TO WHITMAN IN ALBANY COUNTY; Republican Leaders Promise Him 5,000 Plurality, but Indications Point to Smaller Vote. LOCAL PRIDE AN ELEMENT Glynn Has Other Claims, Too, on His Home District ;- Many Sulzer Followers in the Country.
leadPara: ALBANY, Oct. 20. -- If aggressive campaigning by as smooth working a political machine as can be found anywhere in the United States can do it, District Attorney Whitman will carry the political bailiwick of William Barnes by a respectable plurality. It won't be what people here call an old-fashioned Republican victory.

headline: ONEIDA CLAIMED BY REPUBLICANS; Has Gone Democratic Since 1910, but District Reports Show Change of Sentiment. HINMAN MEN BURY HATCHET Both Whitman and Glynn Defeated There In Primaries ;- Davenport and Sulzer Strength a Puzzle.
leadPara: UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Once a Republican stronghold, Onieda County has yielded Democratic majorities or pluralities since 1910. The early indications in this campaign justify the prediction that on election day Oneida will be found in the Republican column again.
abstract: H. P. Snyder candidate from Oneida County

headline: PROMISE WHITMAN 5,000 IN JEFFERSON; Republican Leaders Sure of a Big Vote ;- Democrats Dispute the Figures. SLUMP OF PROGRESSIVES Vote Has Steadily Declined ;- Sulzer Likely to Cut Into Vote of Both Parties.

headline: SAVE CITY OFFICIAL FROM AN ASSASSIN; Aids Take Pistol from Ex-Employe Who Threatens Deputy Commissioner Harrison. DEMANDED REINSTATEMENT Forty Letters and a Petition to Mayor Mitchel Found In the Prisoner's Pockets.
leadPara: Richard C. Harrison, First Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Docks and Ferries, stepped out of his automobile before the entrance to the offices of his department at Pier A, at the Battery, yesterday morning, ignoring a small group of men loitering there.
abstract: praises Glynn for his appointments

headline: $47,500 FOR BOOKS THAT COST $4,000; Women Paid Ten Times Their Value for Farmer's De Luxe Editions. APPRAISED AT THE TRIAL Roosevelt Portrait, Worth 25 Cents, His Autograph on Army Commission, $10, Expert Says.
leadPara: Experts were called by the Government yesterday at the trial in the Federal District Court before Judge Foster of James J. Farmer, Col. William J. Hartley, and others for making use of the mails to carry on an alleged fraud through the sale of gorgeously bound books to show what was the true market value of the volumes which they sold.

headline: FIND MOOSE ENIGMA IN ONONDAGA VOTE; Republican Plurality Depends on Prophesied Defections from Progressive Ranks. EXPECT SCHOENECK TO AID State Fair Issue May Play Important Part In Election ;- Hendricks Is Not Guessing.
leadPara: SYRACUSE, Oct. 23. -- In Onondaga County, the home of rock-ribbed Republicanism, the Democrats in the coming election will about hold their own. If the predictions made by the Democratic leaders on the basis of a recent canvass of the county are borne out, the Democrats even may exceed a little the 15,158 votes cast for William Sulzer in the Gubernatorial election two years ago.
abstract: Onondaga County leaders expect plurality from defections in Progressive ranks, E. Schoeneck candidate for Lieut. Gov., State Fair an important issue

headline: Contests for Supreme and City Court Judgeships the Feature of the Campaign in New York City
leadPara: There are few local offices to be filled at this election, the most important being two Justices of the Supreme Court for the First District, which includes New York and Bronx Counties, and two Judges of the City Court for New York and Bronx Counties. In Queens a District Attorney is to be chosen and in Richmond County a County Clerk.

leadPara: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24. -- Peace commission treaties, of the kind negotiated between the United States and many foreign countries, were spoken of by President Wilson here today, as the means for "shedding light" on disputes which will make the use of force unnecessary.

headline: DEMOCRATIC GAINS LIKELY IN BROOME; It Is Hinman's Home and Republicans Resent Barnes's Attack on Their Candidate. PLURALITY FOR WHITMAN But Probably Greatly Reduced from Normal ;- Sulzer Strong with Railroaders ;- Little Moose Support.
leadPara: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Every other Republican in Broome County is nursing a grievance. The Democrats of Brooms expect to profit on election day from this condition of the Republican mind in what is known as the most stable Republican County in the southern tier.
abstract: attack by Barnes resented by Broome County

headline: TANNER REPLIES TO GLYNN.; Says Murphy Gave Him Nomination for Controller.
leadPara: The charge that Gov. Glynn received his first nomination as Controller on the Democratic ticket from Charles F. Murphy was made yesterday by Frederick C. Tanner, Republican State Chairman, in a statement attacking Gov. Glynn for his assertion in a speech on Friday, in which he said: "I never had an office from Tammany in my life." Mr. Tanner said:

headline: CONGRESS FIGHT STIRS NATION; "Support the President," Is the Democratic Slogan in All States. TO ELECT 34 SENATORS Popular Vote, for the First Time, Will Select One-third of the Upper House. REPUBLICANS ARE HOPEFUL Progressives as a Factor in Many Sections Have Been Eliminated ;- Apathy Fast Disappearing.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The political campaigns throughout the country which will end in the elections of Nov. 3 are remarkable in that they are being waged mainly on national issues. Maters of local concern are involved in the contests in a considerable number of the States of the Union, but as a general rule these are being subordinated to the platforms which the Democrats have expressed in the epigrammatic slogan.

headline: WOMEN'S POLITICAL DEBATE; League for Political Education Plans Busy Winter.
leadPara: The League for Political Education will begin its twenty-first year next Saturday morning in the Hudson Theatre, where three well-known women speakers will discuss "The Issues of the Election as Women See Them." The Republican side will be taken by Helen Varick Boswell, the Democratic by Mrs. Steven B. Ayres, and the Progressive by Miss Alice Carpenter.

headline: FULL TICKETS OF THE PARTIES; State, Legislative, and Congress Candidates Chosen at the Primaries. U.S. SENATOR ON BALLOT Sulzer, Candidate of the Prohibitionists, Enlivens Fight for Governor. SEABURY IN TWO COLUMNS Progressives and Democrats United on Candidate for Court of Appeals Bench.
leadPara: The three major parties -- Democrats, Republicans, and Progressives -- have nominated full tickets for State offices for both branches of the Legislature, Senate and Assembly, for Congress, and for county officials. The minor parties have contented themselves with nominating candidates for State officials, and there are a few independent nominations.

headline: QUIZ CANDIDATES FOR ASSEMBLY; Citizens' Union Submits Questions on Legislation to Come Up in 1915. INDORSES SOME NOMINEES Declarations on Short Ballot, Primary Law Reforms, Home Rule for Cities.
leadPara: The Citizens' Union is the only nonpartisan organization in the city that makes a fight to secure the election of good legislators. Its facilities for examining into the qualifications of candidates is especially adequate since it follows up each session of the legislature and makes annual reports on the services of all New York City members.

headline: WOMEN RUNNING ON MANY TICKETS; Several Are Candidates for Delegates to the Constitutional Convention. PART OF SUFFRAGE PLAN Dr. Katharine B. Davis Tells How Names Were Placed on the Official Ballot.
leadPara: Women, while they have no vote in New York State a yet, have taken an active part in this campaign, and the suffrage movement has made such practical strides that the names of many women appear on the various tickets as candidates. The women's entering wedge into the ranks of office seekers asking for votes is as candidates for delegates to the Constitutional Convention.

headline: SULZER DOMINATES HIS AMERICAN PARTY; Deposed Governor Is Only State Candidate to Run Under Liberty Bell. HE WANTS TO BEAT GLYNN Republicans Say He Will Hurt Democrats More Than Davenport Will Cut Into Whitman's Vote.
leadPara: When the American Party was formed by a number of disgruntled Democrats and admirers of William Sulzer, who believed that he was impeached, not because he had done wrong in office, but because he had refused to do the bidding of Tammany Hall, the leaders of the Democratic and Republican Parties at once began to figure on the effect that the Sulzer candidacy would have in the present campaign.

headline: A SWISS WAR TAX.; Incomes and Property to Pay ;- Railways Seek Loan of $16,000,000.
abstract: war tax decided on in principle

headline: SOCIALISTS EXPECT WAR TO HELP THEM; Predict 80,000 Votes and Hope for Third Place in the Running. C.E. RUSSELL FOR SENATOR Social Labor Party, a Dissenting Offshoot, Gets on Official Ballot This Year by Petition.
leadPara: While the leaders of the Socialist Party in this State realize that they have no chance of electing their ticket this Fall, they predict that the party will poll approximately 80,000 votes, or an increase of 30 per cent. over Charles Edward Russell's vote for Governor in 1912. Russell got 56,917.

headline: IN THE SUPREME COURT OF CIVILIZATION; THE CASE OF The Double Alliance vs. The Triple Entente THE DOUBLE ALLIANCE VS. THE TRIPLE ENTENTE
leadPara: LET us suppose that in this year of dis-Grace, Nineteen Hundred and Fourteen, there had existed, as let us pray will one day exist, a Supreme Court of Civilization, before which the sovereign nations could litigate their differences without resort to the iniquitous and less effective appeal to the arbitrament of arms.

headline: AUTOS DELIVER MUCH BREAD NOW; Great Change Has Come About in Three Years, Says Frank J. Staedtler. AN AID TO CLEANLINESS He Tells Bakers' Convention of This and Other Advantages of Motor Service.
leadPara: In a paper read at the Kansas Bakers' Convention, Frank J. Staedtler recently described the growing importance of motor delivery wagons in the baking business. He said in part:

headline: CITIZENS' UNION LISTS DELEGATES; Questions Candidates as to Their Views on Many Convention Subjects. TO JUDGE QUALIFICATIONS Indorses Some and Approves Others in Carefully Prepared Voters' Directory. NO COMMENT ON MANY MEN Some of the Most Prominent Nominees Declined to Answer the Interrogatories.
leadPara: The New York City Constitutional Convention Committee and the Citizens' Union are conducting active, but separate campaigns to secure the election of fit delegates to the Constitutional Convention. Both organizations, as a result of zealous efforts, have obtained a mass of information concerning the candidates.

headline: SULZER IS A THORN IN CHEMUNG'S G.O.P.; Urged to Withdraw and Swing His Railroad and Farmer Support to Whitman. GLYNN LEADS IN COUNTY Mix-Up in the Southern Tier -Three Will Divide the Republican Vote for Congress.
leadPara: ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- In Chemung County, the heart of the Southern Tier, the Democrats are becoming more hopeful as Election Day draws nearer, Gov. Glynn will carry Chemung by a plurality variously estimated at from 700 to 1,000.
abstract: Chemung County leaders urge Sulzer to withdraw and give support to Whitman

headline: COLONEL WHACKS BOSSES.; "We Are Not Hitting Soft," He Tells Pennsylvania Audiences.
leadPara: WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Oct. 26. -Col. Theodore Roosevelt today started a four-day tour of Pennsylvania in behalf of the Progressive State candidates with a call to voters for the overthrow of corrupt political machines as the one vital need of national politics. The Colonel made eighteen set speeches and a number of extemporaneous talks at overflow meetings today.
abstract: attacks bosses in Penn. speeches

headline: RELIGIOUS ISSUE FACTOR AT BUFFALO; Guardians of Liberty, Fighting Glynn as Catholic, Indorse Whitman and Mixed Ticket. SAY THEY NUMBER 34,000 Republican Leaders Not Pleased at Indorsement ;- Both Old Parties Claim Erie County.
leadPara: BUFFALO, Oct. 26. -- With election only a week off, the outcome in Erie County is greatly in doubt. On the strength of the favorable impression made by District Attorney Charles S. Whitman at the immense meeting he addressed here last Saturday night, the Republican leaders claim the county by 6,000.
abstract: Hamlin indorsed for Lieut. Gov. by Guardians of Liberty, Erie County vote will be heavy

headline: WHITMAN ATTACKS STATE APPOINTEES; Reads Long List of Tammany Men in Controller's Office at Albany. CHEERED BY BIG CROWD Mr. Choate Suggests Reform In Adopting Constitutional Amendments at Meeting in Durland's.
leadPara: The argument that Tammany would attempt to control the State Constitutional Convention for the purpose of tampering with the constitutional safeguards about the election law and of enacting other vicious legislation that the State Constitution now prevents, was made last night by speakers at the Constitutional Convention meeting under the auspices of the Republican Club at Durland's Riding Academy.
abstract: Whitman attacks his appointment

headline: MONROE TO GIVE WHITMAN A BIG VOTE; But Fusion on Local Candidates May Defeat Some of the Republicans. SULZER LOSES POPULARITY Expected to Pull Only a Railroad Vote ;- Progressive Strength Is Declining.
leadPara: ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Monroe County will live up to its traditions and return pluralities for the candidates on the Republican State ticket. It will also vote to return to their seats in the House of Representatives the two Republicans from the Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth Congress Districts.
abstract: letter of praise from Sen. Root

headline: COST OF WADSWORTH'S RACE; Campaign Expenditures $7,687.35, Colby's $1,194.75.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Returns of campaign expenditures received so far by the Secretary of the Senate show that James W. Wadsworth, the Republican nominee in New York, has both received and expended far more than Bainbridge Colby, his Progressive opponent.

headline: PREDICTS GERMAN RETREAT.; Paris Press Looks for the Evacuation of France.
leadPara: PARIS, Oct. 28. -- French newspapers express confidence in the Allies' resistance between Nieuport and Arras, and comment with satisfaction on the continually increasing distance from Paris of the most important battle centre.

headline: STRAUS CHIDES INDORSERS.; Deplores Sectarian Issue Raised by Guardians of Liberty.

Straus, candidate for Delegate-at-Large to the Constitutional Convention, although indorsed in a circular sent out by the Guardians of Liberty, has protested because they have injected a sectarian issue into the present campaign by opposing Gov. Glynn on the ground that he is a Catholic, Mr. Straus has written to Chauncey J. Hamlin of Buffalo, Progressive nominee for Lieutenant Governor, as follows:
abstract: Oscar S. Straus deplores religious issue

headline: ROOSEVELT TELLS OF WHITMAN DEAL; Says He Appointed Tom Foley's Man in Return for Votes in Senate. CHARGES BROKEN PLEDGES Heckled in Cooper Union, the Colonel Outpoints His Interrupters Amid Cheers. "I DID SMASH TAMMANY" When He Was Police Commissioner and Governor, Wigwam "Never Had a Look-In."
leadPara: An audience that packed Cooper Union and overflowed into the corridors refused to become enthusiastic over the issues of the campaign presented by Col. Theodore Roosevelt last night, but it became as noisy and tumultuous as a crowd at a world's series game when toward the close of his speceh the Progressive leader put down his manuscript and had some exciting encounters with hecklers.
abstract: Roosevelt tells of his deal with Tom Foley

headline: LEFT SULLIVAN ALONE FOR HOURS; Warden Admits at Glynn Inquiry Bank Wrecker Had Full Liberty in This City. BORROWED CASH FOR AUTO McCormick Says Riley Told Him the State Would Reimburse Him Later. HEARING ANGERS CROPSEY District Attorney Says Baldwin Is Not Bringing Out All the Facts.
leadPara: OSSINING, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Admissions made by Thomas J. McCormick, the suspended Warden, at Gov. Glynn's inquiry, held in Sing Sing Prison today, revealed that David A. Sullivan, wrecker of the Union Bank of Brooklyn and a prisoner in Sing Sing, had spent four hours in New York City without being under guard.
abstract: to bolt Bensel for J. B. Burnhan and L. Collis on Progressive ticket

headline: THE KNOW-NOTHING TICKET.
leadPara: In Erie County, and presumably elsewhere, the organization called the Guardians of Liberty, which is trying to inject religious issues into the campaign, has made up a ticket of candidates chosen from the Republican and Progressive tickets. This ticket is headed with the name of CHARLES S. WHITMAN for Governor.
abstract: The Know-nothing party, editorial

headline: DELEGATES TICKET OF CITIZENS' UNION; Non-Partisan Organization Recommends Fifteen Candidates. TAKEN FROM ALL PARTIES Urges the Importance of Marking the Ballot for Each of the Nominees for Convention.
leadPara: The Citizens' Union has picked what it calls a model ticket of Delegates-atLarge to the Constitutional Convention from the forty-five Democratic, Republican, and Progressive candidates, and in a statement issued yesterday it calls the attention of the voters throughout the State to the qualifications of the candidates it has selected and urges the importance of their election.

headline: COLORADO DEMOCRATS LEAD.; Betting Favors Election of Senator Thomas and T.S. Patterson.
leadPara: DENVER, Col., Oct. 31 -- Democratic success in the Senatorial, Congressional, and Gubernatorial contests, to be decided on Tuesday, seem certain in Colorado. Betting favors the dominant party in poolrooms, and odds are also offered that the Statewide prohibition amendment to the Constitution will be defeated by at least 11,000 majority.

leadPara: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Republican and Democratic leaders tonight appear optimistic as to the result of the polls on next Tuesday. While the Democrats, in a statement issued tonight by the National Congressional Committee, said they would control the House in the next Congress be a majority of 100 members, they admit privately that their majority may fall below fifty.

headline: IOWA VOTERS APATHETIC.; Light Vote Expected, with Cummins Cohorts Confident.

headline: NEW HAMPSHIRE SITUATION.; Senator Gallinger Having the Fight of His Life for Re-election.

leadPara: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- An impartial survey of all the counties of Pennsylvania leads to the conclusion that United States Senator Boles Penrose, about whose candidacy for re-election has raged the fiercest fight this State has witnessed in years, will win next Tuesday over Representative A. Mitchell Palmer, Democrat, and Gifford Pinchot, Progressive. In all probability the entire Republican ticket will go through to victory with Penrose.

leadPara: Col. Theodore Roosevelt, after a hard day spent in campaigning, arrived at the Brooklyn Academy of Music at 10:30 o'clock last night and ran down to the footlights to the accompaniment of a hearty burst of applause. The gathering was very decorous and there were few cheers.

leadPara: BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- It would cause no general surprise if the entire Democratic State ticket won in Massachusetts next Tuesday. At the same time, the Republicans are admittedly putting up a hard fight, and there are serious defections in the Progressive vote.

headline: HARD FIGHT IN ILLINOIS.; Sullivan Managers Confident ;- "Uncle Joe" Cannon Hopeful.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- In Illinois the choice of a Senator and a Congressional delegation of twenty-seven members constitutes the absorbing feature of next Tuesday's election. Men in Chicago may vote for forty-nine candidates, exclusive of United States Senator, Congressman, Congressman at Large, State Representative, and State Senator, while women's curtailed suffrage privilege places twenty-one candidates as the maximum they can vote for.

headline: NO ISSUE IN ARKANSAS.; Only One Change Expected in the Congress Delegation.

leadPara: HOW will the present war affect our immigration census? Viewed in the light of recent events, however, some of his conclusions take on an added significance.

headline: GOV. GLYNN TO WIN IF CITY ROLLS UP USUAL PLURALITY; Final Forcasts, in Face of Complicated Situation, Show He Is in the Lead. headline: DIVIDED IN MICHIGAN.; Gov. Ferris, Democrat, Favored in Forecast Over Chase S. Osborn.
leadPara: DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 31. -- Comparison of the reports of the various State Central Committees seem to show that Gov. Woodbridge N. Ferris (Dem.) will be re-elected next Tuesday; that the remainder of the Republican ticket will be elected; that the Legislature will be Republican by an increased majority, and that tile Republicans will gain one seat in Congress.

headline: CLOSE IN CALIFORNIA.; Gov. Johnson 10 to 7 Favorite ;- Phelan Leads for Senator.
leadPara: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31. -- With a three-cornered fight for Governor and a similar situation in the Senatorial fight, the result of the election in California next Tuesday is subject to many forecasts. However, careful students of politics virtually are agreed that Hiram Johnson, incumbent and Progressive, will be the next Governor, with John D. Fredericks, the Republican nominee, second, and John B. Curtin, the Democratic nominee, third.

headline: GILLETTE AT LAST CAPITULATES TO AN INTERVIEWER; The Actor-Author Breaks His Long Self-Imposed Rule of Silence and Talks Delightfully About His Ideas of the Actor's Art -and the Playwright's, Too.

leadPara: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 1. -- Engagements which Senator Robert M. La Follette had made for campaign speeches tomorrow in support of J.J. Blaine, the Independent-Progressive candidate for Governor, have been canceled. Senator La Follette planned a three-day whirlwind campaign of the State, to wind up on the day before election, but on the first day he was forced, for lack of crowds, to cancel three of the scheduled speeches.
abstract: Sen. La Follette breaks down and speech in support of J. J. Blaine stopped; E. L. Philipp sues State newspapers for slander

headline: ASSERTS ROOSEVELT WILL NOT RUN IN 1916; Hotchkiss Says Gov. Johnson, If Anybody, Will Head Progressive Ticket. COLONEL AS ADVISOR ONLY Leaders Meet Here, but Meagre Returns from Other States Leave Them Undecided.

headline: MAYOR AND WHITMAN DISCUSS CITY BILLS; One to Abolish Coroners May Not Be Made an Administration Measure. OTHERS KILLED LAST YEAR Mr. Mitchel Says He Found Governor-Elect 'Sympathetic' ;- Their first Meeting In 14 Months.
leadPara: Gov.-elect Whitman and Mayor Mitchel had a long conference yesterday at Mr. Whitman's home, 37 Madison Avenue, concerning city and State legislation. It was the first time the Mayor and Mr. Whitman had met in friendly conference since before the mayoralty election of 1913.
abstract: bill for abolition discussed by Mayor and Whitman
